item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Motoring Editor

tol-text:ooyalaVideo.tol-text:headline: Range Rover Sport: Australian test drive
tol-text:ooyalaVideo.tol-text:teaser: SUN Motors Editor Ken Gibson goes down under with rugby legend Lawrence Dallaglio to test the latest British export

tol-text:enclosure.caption: SUN Motors Editor Ken Gibson goes down under with rugby legend Lawrence Dallaglio to test the latest British export

item.tol-text:story:
THEY love 4x4s Down Under so Oz was perfect for testing the new Range Rover Sport.

The Blue Mountains and the Bathurst Racing Circuit were the venues and everyone was impressed, including rugby’s Lawrence Dallaglio – a Land Rover Global Ambassador – and our Aborigine guide Gumba Wakka Wakka.

THE original Range Rover Sport was a success, despite being flawed.

Nearly 400,000 have been sold worldwide since 2006. So imagine how many will sell when buyers find out how much better the all-new version is.

The new Sport lives up to its name — Range Rover’s upstart little brother has come of age, big time.

It is a big SUV capable of outrageous things off-road and storming around a race circuit like a sportscar. Its talents have stretched in every direction, from head-turning design and limousine luxury to its ability to now carry up to seven people in style. And as the starting price is nearly £20,000 cheaper than the non-sport Range Rover, it does beg a question.

Who needs its big brother?

The reality is the more stately version will still appeal to those customers drawn by the fact it is 4x4 royalty. But I can see BMW, Audi, Mercedes and Porsche SUV drivers switching to the more souped-up and sophisticated Sport.

Design boss Gerry McGovern and his team have done brilliantly, transforming the boxy old model into a much sleeker, more powerful style.

It has shed 420kg with its lightweight aluminium body, so it is now as nimble as the British & Irish Lions’ George North at full pelt.

But it is still two tons of motor — easy to forget as it handles so well and takes corners at unbelievable speeds with more accurate steering. It certainly took the Bathurst circuit in its stride. Just how fast you go depends on the engine you choose. The three-litre turbo diesel will surely be the choice of Brits because of nearly 38mpg and its useful turn of speed — 0-60mph in 7.1secs. It tops out at 130mph.

A three-litre V6 petrol cuts 0-60mph time to 6.9secs but fuel economy drops to 26mpg. The monster five-litre V8 reduces 0-60mph to a sportscar-like five seconds and a top speed of 150mph.

‘Wade rivers and power through mud’ Only a fuel economy figure of 22mpg — less than twenty if you really hammer the engine — dampens the V8’s appeal.

Improvements include more room for rear passengers because, despite its weight loss, it’s a couple of inches longer. Rear passengers also get reclining seats and there is more boot space at 784litres.

For the first time there is the option of seven seats. Everything on board has been upgraded in comfort and quality levels — from business class to first-class. The cabin now matches the classic Range Rover but has a sloping centre console and a sporty gear lever instead of the rotary dial gear knob.

You get executive toys and luxury close to a Bentley, plus Land Rover’s All Terrain mode that lets you climb mountains, wade rivers and power through mud and snow at the click of a dial.

But if you fail to recognise serious changes in condition the Range Sport will adapt the suspension and traction by itself. How smart is that?

It’s aimed at active types and has options such as a cycle rack.

Just don’t be like me and go for a mountain bike ride with Lawrence Dallaglio — he’s mad.

But the former Lions great has the perfect credentials to judge the new Range Rover Sport.

A Range Rover Vogue owner for the past ten years, Lawrence had never considered a Sport before. But after two days with me putting it through its paces in the city, across country and in the Australian wilderness he’d changed his mind and ordered a Sport.

He said: “I think it’s an absolutely awesome car. I’ve been blown away by how agile it is. It’s like a top sportsman with every attribute.

“They have taken all the very best of the Range Rover models and put it into this car — but added to it.

“From driving in the city, the Australian bush and even a race circuit, it has done the business wherever we have taken it.”

For me the new Sport is the complete all-rounder with a real touch of class, with prices that range from £51,000 to more than £80,000 for the elite version.

When I crossed the line at Bathurst I was in no doubt that Range Rover have a major new hit on their hands.

Land Rover have taken all the best of the Range Rover and Sport but added an extra dimension. It has really impressed me with how capable it is, especially its road handling and comfort. It is the ultimate allrounder.

And, just like the Lions, it has taken everything Australia could throw at it.

item.title: Kick asso Picasso
item.shortTitle: Kick asso Picasso!
item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Motoring Editor
item.description: C4 Picasso is very eye-catching especially with stunning models draped over it
item.standfirst: THIS C4 Picasso is very eye-catching especially with stunning models draped over it

enclosure.caption: Heels included ... girls check out the paintwork
Bright future ... Citroen DS3 cabriolet

item.tol-text:story:
PICASSO had an eye for beauty so we think he would have approved of the new Citroen model that bears his name.

It’s hard not to look at the C4 Picasso with these two stunning models in front of it – sadly they are not an option with the car.

But after a test drive to the beach, the girls confirmed that the new Picasso achieves its main role of transporting people in comfort and style – thanks in part to its extra leg room.

The Picasso has always stood out from the crowd and the more extrovert styling has clearly been a hit with buyers – Citroen have sold 3million since 1999, nearly 400,000 of them in the UK.

In just three years, they have sold 350,000 DS models — and the figure is growing fast.

A new DS3 cabriolet is on sale for summer and an SUV is on the way.

The only problem with the success of the DS is that Citroen’s mainstream, more functional models have been pushed into the background.

But with those mainstream models still accounting for 80 per cent of their annual European sales, Citroen are fully aware of the need to revitalise the cars that remain their bread and butter.

Citroen UK boss Linda Jackson told me the success of the DS is allowing the firm to cater for two different types of customer and helping to increase overall sales by 15 per cent so far this year.

She said: “DS models are appealing to buyers who want more style and individuality, who like to personalise their cars, whereas our mainstream customers want more practicality and value for money.

“The success of the DS is great but our mainstream models remain very important. They still account for 70 per cent of UK sales and we needed to re-invent our line-up, which is what we are now doing.”

Linda argues that there is no reason why family buyers of mainstream models can’t have a “stylish” car as well as a user-friendly family motor.

The big-selling C4 Picasso — a mainstream model that has always stood out — is the perfect place to start their transformation.

It will be followed by the seven-seater Grand Picasso at the end of the year. After that, the C1 city car will get a facelift next year, followed by the C4.

Citroen are still deciding how to replace their flagship C5 — but it is unlikely to be another “me too” big family car.

The firm are also desperate to get a small compact SUV — like the Peugeot 2008 and the Renault Captur — on to the market.

They are also considering a replacement for the C2 small car.

This week we tested the new C4 Picasso to see if it hits the sweet spot.

ROAD TEST: CITROEN C4 PICASSO

NAMING a car Picasso has proved a masterstroke by Citroen.

It may not be a masterpiece but three million sales have made the Picasso a financial success story and a class leader in the people carrier market.

And the UK has been a big part of the Picasso success, with more than 400,000 sales here since 1999.

Now Citroen think they have come up with an all-new version that will become another collector’s item for family motorists.

Picasso was known for his provocative paintings and Citroen’s motoring version has always brought an injection of much-needed character and controversy to the bland world of people carriers.

The new version continues that trend with a bold, expressive face that sees the trademark double chevron blades stretched into new LED headlights, with daytime running lights above them like eyebrows, and a double grille below.

The side profile is sleeker and more dynamic as the Picasso is 4cm shorter than the current model and sits 1.61cm lower.

Rear LED lights with a 3D effect complete a more dramatic all-round look.

But people carriers remain all about interior space and practicality, which is why we got four stunning models on board to underline that despite being 4cm shorter there is actually 2cm MORE legroom.

The models were impressed with the space and they liked the Picasso’s funky interior.

But obviously children will fit even better into the three rear seats – and they will appreciate things like the full-length panoramic roof.

There is 5.3m of glass in the Picasso, which makes it feel as if you are sitting in a giant goldfish bowl.

Passengers are nicely pampered with options such as massaging seats, soft-relax headrests and a front passenger seat with an aircraft-style leg support.

Doddle Kids and adults will enjoy the connectivity package that has apps to link you with everything from your phone, music choices to Twitter and the internet.

But the two large digital screens – 7in and 12in – on the dash seem a bit like overkill, as well as being a distraction for the driver at times.

The driver will like the option of a 360° vision camera and a park-assist system that means all he or she has to do is follow the instructions to accelerate or brake. It makes parking a doddle.

Boot space has increased from 537 litres to 630 with the rear seats up. Fold them down and the space hits a van-like 1,700-plus litres.

The front passenger seats also fold to cater for awkward loads up to 2.5m, so the Picasso is definitely family-friendly.

It is also bank account-friendly when it comes to fuel, thanks to a range of new, more efficient diesel and petrol engines. They are led by a 1.6litre diesel with a clutchless gearbox that returns 74mpg and road tax-free 98g/m CO2.

All the 1.6litre and 2litre diesel engines offer a good combination of refinement, performance and around 60mpg, while the 1.6litre turbo petrol is quick and you still get between 45 and 55mpg.

The new C4 Picasso handles and drives considerably better than the current model. It feels more agile thanks to its lower and more compact size, along with revised suspension and the fact it is 140kg lighter.

So Citroen have delivered a mainstream model with a touch of individuality that will appeal to style-conscious family car buyers.

And with prices ranging from £17,500 to £24,500, it’s highly competitive with the current model.

But it is a much better car, making it the value for money that Citroen buyers expect.

KEN GIBSON

item.title: Hot Lex
item.shortTitle: We road test the IS 300hF Sport
item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Sun Motoring Editor
item.description: LEXUS are trying hard to grab your attention, so I took to the road in the F-Sport hybrid
item.standfirst: LEXUS are trying hard to grab your attention, so I took to the road in the F-Sport hybrid that features an in-your-face design
item.tol-text:story:
LEXUS are trying hard to grab your attention.

Not only are their models getting a radical restyling, their advertising goes under the full-on banner Amazing Emotion.

It’s quite a turnaround for a car firm previously not very big at all on emotion — Lexus used to be all about superior quality and customer service.

They were a safe, if uninspiring, premium brand that appealed to buyers wanting something different without rocking the boat.

It got Lexus established and has seen them clock up 5.6million sales since they were set up in 1989 as the luxury arm of Toyota.

Aggressive American buyers fell in love with Lexus but the rest of the world has proved tougher to crack.

Lexus sold 45,610 cars in Europe last year — fewer than the number of 3 Series cars BMW shifted in the UK.

In fact, Lexus’s progress has slowed in recent years, largely because of the economic state of Europe.

So they are now looking at reinventing themselves with a much more aggressive, style-led range.

They also plan to extend their line-up in the next two years, with a compact SUV and a new coupe/cabriolet version of their IS junior executive car.

Here I report on my test-drive of the IS — Lexus’s key model for kick-starting sales, particularly across Europe.

ROAD TEST: LEXUS IS 300hF SPORT

THE original IS summed up the Lexus brand – a premium alternative to the Germans but not quite good enough to beat them.

The all-new version is a far more radical affair, especially the F-Sport hybrid I tested.

It gets an in-your-face design that features a gaping double grille flanked by sparkling headlights and LED running lights.

The side profile gets sharp crease lines in the doors and rear wing, while a ballsy back view dominated by long, slashing, diamond rear lights fills the IS with visual interest.

It’s a much more imposing look, which now makes the BMW 3 Series, Audi A4 and Mercedes C Class look safe and predictable – like Lexus used to be. The much racier feel is carried over into the interior, which takes design cues from Lexus’s LFA supercar.

The cabin has a cockpit flavour, with the easy-to-handle instruments wrapped around the driver, who is separated from his passenger by a thick centre console.

The interior’s fit and finish is all top quality, from the lavish leather seats to the stylish door trim.

The driving seat position completes the much sportier package as you sit lower and cocooned, while the rear passengers are treated to an extra 85mm of leg room. Head room is tight for tall adults though.

Lexus are putting their faith in hybrid/petrol engines and offer no diesel option, which will be seen by many as a weakness.

But in many ways the 2.5litre petrol/hybrid is a cracker. It’s stunningly refined, quiet as a Rolls-Royce whisper. But it sure packs a punch, with 178bhp from the petrol engine and a further 141bhp kicking in from the electric motor.

You get zero emission in pure electric mode and still just 109g/km of carbon emissions – great for company buyers, as is the economy rating of between 50mpg and 60mpg.

The only problem is the E-CVT gearbox, which is unresponsive and seems to be constantly hunting for gears when you drive it hard. It needs a full auto or good manual design, because even using the F1-style paddles fails to improve matters.

Yet the IS’s crisp steering is better than an Audi A4, a match for the Merc C-Class and only just pipped by a BMW 3 Series.

In SE trim, the IS300h is only marginally more expensive than a mid-spec 2litre diesel from Lexus’s German rivals, but the 300hF Sport pushes the price to £33,495.

The IS 300hF Sport is a real alternative to the Germans – but is likely to remain a niche car until Lexus improve the gearbox in the hybrid, or offer a good diesel.

item.title: Vauxhall put their shirt on England
item.shortTitle: Vauxhall put their shirt on England
item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Motoring Editor
item.description: WILL high-profile contract help Vauxhall sell more cars
item.standfirst: VAUXHALL secure high-profile contract as sponsors of England football team. Our footie-mad Motors Ed sees if this will help them sell cars

enclosure.caption: Sponsorship ... Vauxhall banking on England success
Rio deal ... Maracana Stadium
Amp it up ... Gary Neville
Roy's toy ... Hodgson
Of Corsa it's good enought for England player ... Ecoflex
Full of attitude ... Tourer

item.tol-text:story:
YOU don’t think of England footballers driving a Vauxhall Astra – they’re more likely to be found in a supercar or Range Rover.

Which begs the question: What do Vauxhall get for their four-year deal in excess of £20million to sponsor the England team?

And how big a disaster would it be for them if England don’t make it to next year’s World Cup finals in Brazil? Losers don’t sell cars.

Vauxhall’s managing director Duncan Aldred is praying as much as team boss Roy Hodgson and thousands of fans that the national side reach the finals.

Aldred is an England fan — but first and foremost a hard-nosed businessman who knows he needs a serious return on his major investment in the side.

He says the deal is a long-term investment and not dependant on the Three Lions getting to Brazil.

But he admits: “I am desperate the team make it to the World Cup finals.The exposure and value of being in a major tournament is a lot higher, the awareness is dramatically higher.”

He says: “Our research shows that car buyers’ awareness of Vauxhall has increased by ten per cent and they are more likely to buy a Vauxhall because of the sponsorship, which is massive.

“And it shows us the sponsorship works and does help to sell cars — it has lifted the brand.”

I sat with him watching England in their friendly match against Brazil in the Maracana Stadium. He smiled as the Vauxhall name flashed up on billboards in front of 80,000 fans and a television audience of millions.

Aldred was equally happy spending the evening with supporters at a Fans’ Zone in Rio de Janeiro.

Sponsored by Vauxhall, fans had the chance to meet Sir Trevor Brooking and other ex-players such as Danny Mills.

This is part of Vauxhall and the FA’s plans to give England supporters a better deal when they watch the team at Wembley and in far-flung places.

Matches are the high-profile spotlight that mega-bucks sponsorship can shine on your brand.

And it goes further than the name on billboards, kit and about 200 cars and vans being driven by FA staff.

The sponsorship is being invested by the FA into improving facilities and coaching at a national and grassroots level around the country.

Aldred says the sponsorship is a key component in showing the scale of ambition Vauxhall have to become the UK’s top-selling car brand — and preferred choice of the British mainstream car-buying public.

It’s also a great showcase for their most dramatic line-up of new cars in their 113-year history.

Aldred says that although there is good awareness of Vauxhall in the UK, many potential buyers don’t realise the major changes made in recent years.

And he believes sponsoring England gives Vauxhall a real connection with the British public.

He says: “We wanted to display our British identity and 113-year heritage of making cars in the UK.

“We want to connect with the British public and what better way than sponsoring the country’s football teams?

“We want to stretch the appeal of the brand and make it aspirational, but still affordable.”

It’s not only the senior England squad that Vauxhall sponsor. They support all age groups as well as the women’s teams and the England Disabled Team.

But Aldred is aware that just as a good performance in Brazil would bring a feelgood factor, failure to qualify or a poor showing would mean Vauxhall being associated with an England flop.

He believes the deal is a great shop window for their new models such as the Adam city car, Mokka SUV and Cascada convertible, as well as household names like the Astra and Corsa.

He says the sponsorship also gives Vauxhall a link to thousands of young fans — car buyers of the future.

Part of the package gives Vauxhall access to England’s top players and Wayne Rooney, above, is designing his own version of the Adam city car.

It’s a clever move that helps illustrate the huge potential to personalise a car that is Vauxhall’s answer to the Mini.

Players also meet Vauxhall dealers, owners and the firm’s workforce, as well as taking coaching sessions.

I saw England coach and former player Gary Neville hold a session at the FA’s training HQ at St George’s Park near Burton, Staffs.

He met a squad of Under 14 players from Doncaster who are sponsored by a local Vauxhall dealer.

Neville says: “Football at grassroots level is crucially important to producing the England players of the future, and these events give us a chance to meet and encourage young players.”

Although Neville says he is not a big car fan, he is impressed with his electric/hybrid Vauxhall Ampera that runs on electric and a petrol motor.

He says: “I’ve had the car a year and only filled it up five times, because most of my trips I can run on pure electric. I also like the silence of the car because it’s a very stress-free place to travel.”

England players Glen Johnson and Phil Jagielka are also driving Amperas, while Hodgson has an Insignia.

Vauxhall are clearly investing heavily and taking a gamble in their England sponsorship deal.

They know that football can be a winning formula — but that success is not guaranteed.

Vauxhall also know that England need to deliver on the pitch if they are to reap the rewards in their showrooms. Failure does not bear thinking about.

‘70mpg and no road tax, a real England favourite’

ROAD TEST: VAUXHALL CORSA ECOFLEX

THE only time an England footballer might have owned a Vauxhall Corsa was as their first car as an apprentice.

But I think every England player should be forced to drive a Corsa as a reality check to remember what life is like in the real world.

They would be surprised by how good a modern Corsa is, just as I was when I tried the latest model.

Despite being one of the older superminis on the block, the Corsa still looks good alongside new rivals and it remains consistently in the top three best-selling cars in the UK.

The EcoFlex 1.3 turbo diesel I tested offers a double whammy – super-clean 88g/km of CO2 emissions, which means no road tax, plus close to 70mpg with a light right foot.

The engine is quiet, refined and reasonably nippy for a supermini, all of which mean it is ideal for city commuters. And, unlike superminis of the past, it is quite capable of coping with a long motorway drive in a degree of comfort.

The Corsa is still the UK’s third-best selling car, and an all-new version is due next year.

Corsa prices start at £9,495 and even this EcoFlex at £15,410 is loose change for a footballer.

‘As menacing as Rooney with a real turn of pace’

ROAD TEST: VAUXHALL VXR8 TOURER

IF one car in the Vauxhall range might appeal to the extravagant motoring tastes of England players it would be the VXR8 Tourer.

In fact, I think it would be the perfect wheels for Wayne Rooney – lots of attitude, in your face, but with the ability to perform.

There is nothing subtle about the VXR8 Tourer estate, hardly surprising when you consider it is based on an Australian muscle car.

And it looks as menacing as Rooney after he’d been subbed by Sir Alex Ferguson.

But when you flatten the accelerator the VXR8 is a real firebrand, with a thumping 6.2-litre V8 capable of getting close to supercar speeds.

And the engine sounds like thunder as 0-60mph takes only 4.9 seconds, while top speed is limited to 155mph.

Economy is not the VXR Tourer’s strong point. Drive it to the max and it drops to around 17mpg. But you can get close to 30mpg if you treat it gently.

For a big, bulky estate it handles well and can be thrown around with a degree of confidence – although the steering is heavy and the gear changes demand a firm hand. On the inside, the cabin feels like an Aussie attempt at luxury.

It has all the bells and whistles of similarly- priced European rivals – but not quite the finish you’d expect from a £50,000 executive car.

It is, though, seriously comfortable. The sports seats are like two big armchairs and it is big on space, with a huge boot that could carry all the training gear of the modern footballer.

Like certain footballers, the VXR8 Tourer is full of attitude but likely to be an acquired taste.

That means it will also be exclusive – perfect for an England player.

item.title: Why Nissan is REAL Angel Of The North
item.shortTitle: Why Nissan is REAL Angel Of The North
item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Sun Motoring Editor
item.description: THE Nissan plant has become the industrial heartbeat of the region
item.standfirst: THE Nissan plant has become the industrial heartbeat of the region — the motoring Angel Of The North and the jewel in UK car industry’s shining crown

enclosure.caption: Nissan's angels ... 7 millions cars and 30,000 jobs
Note-worthy ... Nissan
Niss work ... making Leaf batteries
Attitude ... Juke
Big on space ... Qashqai 360

item.tol-text:story:
NISSAN have become one of the most inventive and bold mainstream car makers in the past few years.

The Japanese firm have always been willing to take a risk with models such as the original Eighties Micra, the 350Z coupé and the GT-R supercar saloon.

But in 2006 they went right out on a limb when the totally different Qashqai broke the mould of traditional family hatchbacks.

Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn said he was tired of “me too” lookalike hatchbacks, and that the firm’s Almera replacement would start a new trend.

The Qashqai did just that with its unique styling that was a crossover between a hatchback and a compact SUV, aimed at family motorists wanting something different.

The Qashqai was clearly what motorists had been waiting for.

It was an overnight success and now, six years later, is consistently one of Britain and Europe’s favourite cars and has sold nearly 1.6million models.

And when the rest of the car industry follow you, as they did with the Qashqai, you know your on to a real winner.

In the first four months of 2013 the Qashqai’s popularity remains as strong as ever. It’s the UK’s sixth best-selling car and has already clocked up nearly 20,000 sales.

Nissan quickly realised they had found a new motoring niche with the Qashqai and followed it up with the even more radical Juke.

The impossible-to-ignore Juke was a pumped-up supermini that looked like a cross between a baby SUV and a coupé.

It was a model that split opinion and still does — motorists either love or loathe the Juke.

Fortunately for Nissan, it’s more of love affair and sales are closing in on 400,000 in less than three years.

Now Nissan believe they have found another niche to add to the Juke’s success with a feisty new performance Nismo version and, once again, they appear to have scored a bull’s-eye.

They planned to sell just 600 in the UK this year but demand has been so strong that number has now been increased to 1,000.

Both the Juke and Qashqai are built at Nissan’s Sunderland factory, which is currently looking to produce more than 500,000 vehicles this year, making it the most productive car plant in Europe.

The factory has also just started production of the Leaf — the bestselling all-electric vehicle in the world.

Nissan have also built a plant at Sunderland to supply batteries for the Leaf, creating a further 300 jobs.

At the moment, production is just 60 a day, small numbers compared with the 2,185 Qashqais and Jukes rolling off the lines every day.

But Nissan believe electric motoring and the Leaf will play an increasingly important role in the long-term future of motoring.

And, this summer, the factory gears up to produce an all-new version of the Note — a small car the Japanese firm expect to appeal to British motorists in the same way as the Qashqai and Juke.

The last Note was a mini people carrier that was more old-school and although it sold reasonably, it failed to capture the imagination.

Nissan have rethought the idea and made the new Note a direct rival to the Fiesta in the supermini class, sitting above their own entry-level Micra, with prices expected to start at about £12,000.

And this time they are giving the Note some style to go with its practicality.

They are also promising it will be a technology leader for small cars, with all the latest connectivity the modern motorist is looking for.

Nissan clearly see the Note regaining them lost sales in the supermini sector, with the current Micra losing its sparkle and many of the customers that made it such a huge favourite with British buyers in the Eighties and Nineties.

Nissan built more than 2.3million Micras at Sunderland but that took more than 18 years.

We get a first drive of the Note next month and if they have repeated the winning formula of the Qashqai and Juke, they could once again have a supermini to rival the success of the original Micra.

ROAD TEST: JUKE NISMO

THE Juke has always been the small car that’s big on attitude.

Now Nissan are giving it performance to match the design attitude by creating a Nismo version.

They see the Nismo range becoming the equivalent of Ford’s RS and ST, Vauxhall’s VXR and Renault’s Sport.

You can tell instantly it is the unruly member of the Juke pack – with a body makeover that gives it an extra edge.

The in-your-face front end looks more menacing. It has a black/chrome mesh grille and a lower grille with red piping and body skirts – plus LED running lights to let everyone know that you’re in a Nismo.

Add smoked-grey 18in alloy wheels with wider tyres, extra-flared arches, side skirts and a rear spoiler and there’s no way people won’t see you coming.

The 1.6litre turbo petrol engine gets an extra 10bhp to give it 187bhp of genuine grunt under the bonnet.

That’s quick enough to cut 0-62mph to 7.8 seconds, which should be fast enough for most Juke drivers.

And you can still get close to 40mpg driving the Juke around town.

It’s not quite serious hot-hatch handling, but it will make you smile.

On the inside, the Nismo gets a dark and moody treatment.

But there are flashes of red trim and a red rev counter, drilled metal pedals and suede steering wheel that confirm you are driving a special Juke.

Owners will also be able to download a Nismo iPad app, which can store driving data and even lap times for the serious go-faster drivers.

Juke prices begin at £14,495 but you pay for the extra Nismo clout.

They start off at £19,999 – and rise to £22,195 for the all-wheel-drive auto version.

But with Nissan already sold out and now making extra to meet demand, there are clearly plenty of Juke buyers wanting the Nismo experience.

ROAD TEST: QASHQAI 360

FAMILY car buyers invariably have to compromise.

They want a vehicle to be fashionable and look good – but what they need is a car that is practical to meet the demands of a young family.

What Nissan delivered with the original Qashqai was a no-compromise car that didn’t look like a hatchback – it was more interesting, more roomy – but which cost a similar price. Bingo.

It even came with the option of four-wheel drive for families in rural areas and provided the option of seven seats in the +2 version.

But Nissan have not sat back and basked in the Qashqai’s big sales.

A minor facelift in 2011 smartened up the headlights and grille to give even more visual appeal and now they’ve brought out a 360 version to continue the momentum.

But the attraction of the Qashqai 360 remains the same basic formula – big on space and practicality, with ultra-economical engines and that high-up seating position that mum, dad and the kids like.

Qashqais also come equipped with Bluetooth, satnav, air con, glove box cooler and 360° monitor that gives you a screen view all around the car – perfect for parking.

I tested the 1.6litre diesel – the best engine – which delivers a useful mix of reasonable performance and the now-vital fuel economy figure of just over 60mpg. And it’s tax-friendly at 119g CO2 emissions.

There are also 1.5 and 2litre turbo diesels, plus a 1.6litre turbo petrol.

The Qashqai’s handling is very similar to a hatchback, though not quite as agile on cornering. But it’s still a relaxing and comfortable drive.

Prices for the Qashqai Visia 1.6 petrol are from £16,595 – haggle and you’ll get a few hundred off – with the 360 starting at £19,945 and going up to £27,095 for the seven-seat 4x4 +2 model.

item.title: From cute... to brute
item.shortTitle: What have Fiat done to supercool 500?
item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Sun Motoring Editor
item.description: FIAT have followed Mini’s lead to go XL by expanding the 500 range
item.standfirst: FIAT have followed Mini’s lead to go XL by expanding the 500 range from supermini to a mini people carrier

enclosure.caption: Mini to meanie ... supermini Fiat 500 has been blown up to become 500L

item.tol-text:story:
OH, what have they done to the cutest car on the road?

Fiat have taken the supercool 500 and pumped it up into the bloated and ungainly 500L.

They have been unable to resist expanding the 500 range from supermini to a mini people carrier unashamedly to cash in on the car’s cult status.

Not for the first time, they’ve followed Mini’s lead to go XL with their smallest model — Mini did it with the Countryman — to squeeze out every possible sale.

But it doesn’t work because the 500L doesn’t look like a 500 apart from the headlights and grille, and it certainly doesn’t drive like one.

There’s nothing wrong with the 500L as a car and it delivers the space to make it a genuine family-friendly five-seater.

It rides and drives OK but it’s lost the fun factor of the 500 to become a pretty boring family runabout, although the 0.9litre TwinAir petrol and the 1.3 diesel engines are both useful performers and return over 60mpg.

For me, the awkward styling has lost all of the charm and character of the 500. I think Fiat should have made it a member of their Panda family because it has the quirky style.

The Panda range is all about practicality and that’s the strong point of the 500L, along with a good quality funky cabin.

The L badge adds another extra to the 500 — price.

It starts at £14,995 but there are plenty of alternatives at that price — and more desirable ones still given that the price for the diesel version rises to £16,490.

I’ve also just tested the Panda 4x4, confirming my view that the 500L would have made a good addition to its family. The dinky Panda 4x4 has carved out its own niche in the macho world of SUVs since launching in 1983.

But the latest model is facing serious competition from a raft of new baby 4x4 crossovers, such as the Renault Captur, Peugeot 2008 and especially the no-thrills Dacia Duster 4x4 at £10,995. Even the Panda’s trump card of price is being challenged with the Renault starting at £12,495 and the Peugeot at £12,995, compared with the Fiat’s starting price of £14,950 for the diesel.

But after a week driving the Panda 4x4, I found it still has plenty going in its favour.

There’s something about it — a bit like the animal it’s named after — that makes you smile. The latest model is longer, wider and taller, which makes it even more versatile.

It means this Panda is just as happy in the urban jungle as it is off-road, where it performs remarkably well.

There are 15 stowage places around the cabin and boot space is 225litres, going up to 870litres with the rear seats flat. The interior has also benefited from some styling cues inspired by its 500 baby brother, like the colour-coded dashboard and trendy new patterned seats.

The package is completed by the addition of the excellent 0.9litre twin-turbo three cylinder petrol engine that delivers between 50mpg and 60mpg.

So although this new Panda is under threat from some serious rivals, it still has enough attractions to make sure it’s far from being extinct.

item.title: No flies on this Spider
item.shortTitle: McLaren takes on Italians
item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Sun Motoring Editor
item.description: WE road test McLaren Spider
item.standfirst: VIDEO: IT’S amazing what effect going topless can have. It gives Spider the extra edge — and you want to be noticed

enclosure.caption: Spider fan ... but can McLaren car take on Ferrari
Motoring ... Ken Gibson drives McLaren Spider
Awesome ... P1 hypercar
Ooh la la ... LaFerrari
Supercar ... McLaren Spider
Super ... easy to drive around town

tol-text:ooyalaVideo.tol-text:headline: McLaren Spider - Test drive
tol-text:ooyalaVideo.tol-text:teaser: THE Sun's motors editor Ken Gibson puts McLaren's supercar to the test

item.tol-text:story:
YOU must have something special to take on Ferrari.

Going head-to-head with the Italians is motoring’s Mission: Impossible — but it is a mission Britain’s McLaren are relishing.

Since branching out from the McLaren Formula One team into road cars in 2010, it has been a high-octane performance of non-stop activity.

They have built a state-of-the-art factory and delivered two supercars — the 12C Coupe and the 12C Spider, which last year found 1,400 buyers despite prices ranging from £176,000 to nearly £250,000.

McLaren’s decision to go into road cars has been good news for British workers too, with more than 1,000 jobs created.

Now McLaren are recruiting a further 100 to work at their Woking factory for the next stage of their rapid rise to fully-fledged supercar maker.

The new recruits will be working on the awesome P1 hypercar, due to go on sale later this year.

And the P1 will be starting as epic a battle as any on the racetrack between McLaren and Ferrari, as it takes on the new hybrid LaFerrari.

With prices for the McLaren P1 starting at £866,000 and £1million for the Ferrari, you can see why the supercar arena has suddenly gone hyper.

Performance from the P1 will be even closer to an F1 car, with the 3.8litre V8 engine boosted by an electric motor exploding a combined 903bhp — a crazy amount of horses pulling you on.

It does 0-62mph in less than three seconds, 0-124mph takes less than seven seconds and if you have the balls — and your own racing circuit — the top speed is 217mph.

The carbon fibre P1 has a real drama about it.

Its designer, ex-Ferrari man Frank Stephenson, says: “It had to look dramatic and be beautiful.”

And it is, big time. It will also be very exclusive as McLaren are selling just 375.

They have already sold two-thirds of those. And with another 500 hot prospects being spoken to, it will be sold out very soon.

Only a test drive will reveal who wins the hypercar battle. In truth that is irrelevant, as both cars will sell out.

McLaren have announced they are selling 100 50th anniversary editions of the 12C Coupe and 12C Spider models, with prices from £196,000 to £215,500.

ROAD TEST: McLAREN SPIDER

IT’S amazing what effect going topless can have.

And I’m not talking Page Three girls. I’m talking about what happened when the McLaren 12C went from Coupe to Spider.

The Coupe impressed everyone, including me.

But despite its technical excellence, I felt it lacked the emotion and glamour of a Ferrari.

But in Spider form, roof down, the McLaren gets the extra edge it needed.

Both visually and, more surprisingly, from a driving point of view, it now feels like the total package.

When you chop the roof off a supercar, they normally become compromised. But not the McLaren.

It feels more composed and the electric roof disappears in 17 seconds. It can also be lowered at speeds of up to 19 mph.

Everywhere I went, the Spider turned heads – it has genuine supercar style to match its rivals.

And you want to be noticed at this price. The Spider starts at £195,950 and the model I drove was just under £250,000.

Being a McLaren, it really is a tour de force of technical brilliance, as you’d expect from a company with the latest F1 racing tech on hand.

And you would expect the Spider to have exceptional handling capabilities, coming from a firm run by Ron Dennis – a guy known for his obsession with technical perfection and attention to detail. And it does.

You can actually drive the McLaren around town as easily as a supermini.

Unlike many supercars, it is surprisingly relaxing and comfortable to drive.

It only becomes intimidating when you flatten the accelerator and the 3.8litre V8 twin turbo engine comes alive.

With 616bhp sitting just behind you, there is also a wall of intoxicating noise to go with the thumping performance that sees 0-60mph flash by in a blur of 3.4 seconds, while 0-100mph takes just 7.2 seconds and the top speed is 207mph.

Performance is maximised by super-slick and rapid paddle changes attached to the steering wheel, though you can sit back and enjoy the smooth auto-box driving in town traffic.

But the Spider really loves bends and demanding roads.

The faster you go, the more composed and precise it becomes – to a point that is almost dangerous as it makes the average driver seem multi-talented.

The pared-down cabin feels like a cross between an F1 car and a fighter jet, with a perfectly sized steering wheel that, like the leather sports seat, fits like a glove.

It is luxurious but not flamboyant, apart from the gull wing doors.

Three days with the Spider confirmed McLaren are learning fast. It is a match for the Ferrari 458 Italia – and that is a very big statement to make.

item.title: Is this the cleverest car in the world?
item.shortTitle: Is this the cleverest car in the world?
item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Motoring Editor
item.description: MERCEDES S-Class is the first car that can drive itself and is a limo capable of 64 mpg
item.standfirst: MERCEDES S-Class lives up to Best Car In The World billing by being the first car that can drive itself and is a limo capable of 64 mpg

enclosure.caption: Car Keys ... Alicia performs as Mercedes S-Class is unveiled
Class act ... Alicia Keys at Mercedes S-Class launch in Germany
World Class ... is this the best car in the world?

item.tol-text:story:
IT was one of the most spectacular car launches ever.

A new model billed the Best Car In The World, a singing superstar and the planet’s most advanced aeroplane.

The Mercedes S-Class lived up to its billing – it’s the first car that can drive itself and is a limo capable of 64mpg.

And the Merc was perfectly in tune as its first passenger was Alicia Keys.

The American singer was the star turn at the launch show in Germany.

There was even a thunderstorm as the car drove down the runway and into a hangar at the Hamburg HQ of the Airbus A380, in front of the 800 invited VIP quests.

Here’s the full review from the unveiling of the new Mercedes S-Class

CALLING a new vehicle “the best car in the world” has to be either misplaced arrogance or justified confidence.

That is the risk Mercedes took by making the claim at the VIP launch of their flagship S-Class model in Hamburg.

Just as well, then, that the car appears to have all the qualities to back up the bold boast, including being the first one that can drive itself in heavy traffic!

The steering assist and stop-go pilot mean it can steer, brake and drive itself automatically at speeds of up to 30mph in traffic jams.

The driver can, of course, always regain control.

The car also has a brake system that detects pedestrians or vehicles in front in city traffic, and can self-brake to avoid a crash.

The system can also recognise a potential rear collision and put on the rear hazard lights.

These factors justify another Merc claim — that the S-Class is “the safest car on the road”.

And how about this for a ground-breaking development?

It has the first car suspension with “eyes”. It uses camera scanners — dubbed Magic Body Control — to detect bumps on the road ahead.

When it sees one the vehicle then automatically adjusts the dampers and suspension on each wheel to a firmer or softer setting to give a magic carpet ride across potholed surfaces — perfect for UK roads.

It’s the most economical luxury limo, with a range of hybrid diesel/petrol engines capable of 64mpg — that’s better than most superminis.

Another promise is first-class aircraft levels of comfort and luxury, which was why Mercedes chose the German home of the Airbus A380, the world’s most advanced aircraft, for the launch.

That’s presumably also why stars such as singer Alicia Keys were happy to be there to endorse it.

I can vouch for the unadulterated luxury of the roomy, sumptuously soft leather seats.

The backrests recline to 45 degrees, the heated seats have an energising massage function and even the armrests can be heated or cooled. But it’s not all about relaxation.

You get working desks in the back, plus two DVD screens which can be linked to the web for connectivity, along with a mega-music system, all of which can be operated from an app on your phone.

There’s even a climate control with air balance and an active perfuming system with four different smells to waft around the cabin!

Also, 115 years after cars were first fitted with electric headlamps, the S-Class is the first car since to have virtually NO lightbulbs — although its 500 LEDs mean it won’t leave you in the dark.

The new S-Class is very much the Airbus of motoring.

It’s a trailblazing, advanced trendsetter for business high-fliers when they are on the ground.

Over the years the car has been the best-selling luxury limo.

Alongside its high-spec standards it has always been at the forefront of technology, a winning recipe which has made it the favourite wheels of executives and politicians.

And the new model has much more road presence with its prominent and upright chrome grille, long, raking headlights leading to a long bonnet and a sleek, coupe-like roofline.

We will have to wait to test drive the S-Class to see if it delivers “the best driving experience”, but no other car can touch it for technological innovations and safety.

Only a Rolls or Bentley challenge it for out-and-out luxury — this is five-star motoring.

On sale in the UK this autumn, the price is yet to be confirmed but expect a range from £65,000 all the way up to £170,000.

A fitting price for a car Mercedes believe to be the best in the world.

item.title: Master’s Golf
item.shortTitle: Master’s Golf: First drive of VW’s new GTI
item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Motoring Editor
item.description: WE road tested VW's Polo BlueGT, Beetle Sport and Golf GTI
item.standfirst: WE’VE just driven three VW models, the Polo BlueGT and the Beetle Sport. But we saved the best for last – the latest version of the Golf GTI

enclosure.caption: Beats the competition ... Golf GTI
Blue-tiful ... Polo BlueGT
Bee better ... Volkswagen Beetle is improving on performance
Back ... latest version of Golf GTI
Slick ... six-speed manual or a DSG semi-automatic gearbox

item.tol-text:story:
PERFORMANCE comes in many different guises.

We’ve just driven three VW models, all promising a little extra performance but all with totally different personalities.

For starters, we drove the Polo BlueGT, which sounds very sporty but is actually more warm than hot hatch.

Then we turned up the heat a little to a Beetle Sport with a 2-litre turbo.

But we saved the best for last – VW’s big daddy of performance, the latest version of the Golf GTI.

ROAD TEST: VW POLO BLUEGT

AS with the Golf, the Polo’s success is based around the desirability of the badge compared to its rivals.

And like the Golf, the smaller Polo also gets a hot GTI version but, priced at around £20,000, it’s a very small niche.

Which is why Polo have brought out a slightly less powerful BlueGT version, at a slightly more affordable £18,020.

And the Polo could appeal to more buyers because it’s a nice mix of reasonable performance, sporty-ish looks but, equally important, very impressive fuel economy.

That’s because the BlueGT gets VW’s cylinder de-activation system on its 1.4-litre turbo petrol engine, which basically cuts the cylinders down to three when you’re cruising.

It still performs like a baby GT when you flatten the accelerator: 0-62mph in 7.9 seconds is nippy for a supermini and the top speed is 130mph.

It also handles OK and fits into band B, which means zero road tax in the first year and £20 afterwards.

But drive the GT sensibly and it gets close to 60mpg, which is a pretty reasonable compromise as fuel economy is increasingly becoming more relevant than performance.

ROAD TEST: VW BEETLE

YOU tend to think of the Beetle as being much more about posing than performance.

But the third generation of the Beetle not only looks much sharper than the previous girly model, it also drives better.

Mind you, that’s not saying a great deal.

Affair It has to be said, the last version was a pretty lame affair.

And although the new Sport version won’t ever get you excited, it is now quick enough to make the driving experience a more enjoyable affair.

That is particularly true if you go for the 200bhp 2-litre turbo petrol engine that returns a respectable 0-62mph in 7.5 seconds and has a top speed of 140mph.

But fuel economy drops to just below 39mpg.

The handling fits only into the “adequate” category because, despite its Sport badge, the Beetle is still really all about totally individualistic style.

You pay for the style and the extra performance of the Sport with a £22,995 tag after a recent price rise, which means you really have to like the way this new Beetle looks.

ROAD TEST: VW GOLF GTI

IT was the first family hatchback with the handling and performance of a sports car.

Volkswagen’s reward for creating the Golf GTI has been sales of nearly two million since 1975... and a car that has become an icon.

Over the years since its launch, the GTI has acquired legendary status and become the king of the hot hatches. Its appeal has never waned, especially in the UK where VW have sold more than 225,000.

And after two days’ driving on mountain roads and a race circuit in Provence, I can tell you it sets a new benchmark.

Which is probably just as well because it faces stiff competition from the very good Focus ST, the Astra VXR and a smoky new Seat Leon Cupra, on the way soon.

The success of the GTI has always been its dual personality. It’s a car that is as happy trundling down to the supermarket as it is driving at speed on twisty roads or even a racing circuit.

It’s a car that can do everything with style, including the understated looks. Now it just does it better and, being a VW, it holds its price better than any of its rivals.

The vital element is an amazingly smooth, quick and refined 2-litre turbo engine that delivers 220bhp, with 0-62mph in 6.5 seconds, linked to a slick six-speed manual or a DSG semi-automatic gearbox.

The brilliant thing about the GTI is that it not only feels faster than the mere figures, it feels so effortless. There is no wild torque steer under hard acceleration, thanks to a new steering system.

And the ride is like a magic carpet over bad surfaces — perfect for UK roads — the result of developments to the suspension and great sculpted sports seats in classic tartan upholstery.

The cabin is very Volkswagen, which means top quality materials.

But you also get nice touches such as red ambient lighting and a chunky sports steering wheel to go with the seats and drilled aluminium pedals.

Standard equipment includes park assist with a rear view camera, an excellent touchscreen satnav, 19in alloy wheels and individual climate control air con, plus you get bags of space for four adults and luggage.

There is the option of a Performance Pack, costing an extra £980, that adds 10bhp plus bigger brakes and a limited-slip differential for drivers who like driving on the limit.

But as I said, the GTI is not just about performance.

Emissions are down to 139g/km for the manual and fuel economy is impressive at between 44 and 47mpg, though closer to 40mpg driven hard. Insurance has dropped 5 groups.

The Golf GTI has never been the cheapest but it’s still good value, from £25,845 to £28,895 for the Performance Pack version.

But don’t take my word for it.

Take a test drive. I guarantee you will be blown away by this class act.

item.title: All-new Mondeo’s still on the way-o
item.shortTitle: All-new Mondeo’s still on the way-o
item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Motoring Editor
item.description: FIRST drive of Graphite as Mondeo Man waits for new version
item.standfirst: MONDEO Man should be driving a new model but is being offered two special-edition versions of current one. We had first drive of Graphite

enclosure.caption: New version ... Ford Mondeo
First drive ... Ford Graphite

item.tol-text:story:
MONDEO MAN used to be the politicians’ barometer for the mood of the country at election time.

Now the car he drives is caught up in motoring politics — over Ford’s plans to close a Belgian factory.

Mondeo Man should be driving an all-new model but, instead, is being offered two special-edition versions of the current one.

Ford have been forced to delay the stunning new version until late next year due to their factory dispute.

The Mondeo is built in the Belgian city of Genk but Ford want to shut that plant and move production to Spain.

But that can’t go ahead until Ford have completed formal consultations with the Belgian government and trade unions, who are fighting the plan.

They need to do this to comply with Belgian law, although the closure is certain to go ahead regardless.

Ford are also in the middle of talks with union leaders in the UK over their decision to shut down the company’s Transit works in Southampton and a components plant in Dagenham, Essex, this year.

Again, there is strong resistance to the plans.

The proposed closures in both Belgium and the UK are part of Ford’s plans to curb major losses in their European operation.

They forecast £1.3billion losses for the full year, with those for the first quarter already up from £96million to £298million.

Which is why the new Mondeo remains under wraps here, despite the fact this British/ European designed and engineered car has been on sale in America for nearly a year and will shortly be hitting showrooms in China.

The new Mondeo is getting rave reviews in America — not surprisingly because it looks like an Aston Martin from the front and has German-style quality on the inside.

But with the new car not due here until late next year, Ford have been forced to bring out two special-edition versions and revamp the current range to keep the Mondeo competitive until then.

We tested one of the specials, the new entry-level Mondeo Graphite, to see how it performs.

FIRST DRIVE: MONDEO GRAPHITE

FEW mainstream cars have aged better than the Mondeo.

Of its mainstream rivals, only the new Mazda 6 really outshines it in the style department.

But the Mondeo is now six years old and that’s elderly by car standards, where mainstream models are changed every five years.

The Mondeo, though, has had a major mid-life face-lift.

And Ford have consistently updated its engine technology.

In fact, the 1.6litre diesel Graphite model is a cracker. I got just over 50mpg driving the car hard and Ford’s official figure is 65mpg. Driven with a light right foot, 60mpg would be realistic.

With an engine that’s part of a topnotch driving package, that’s great news for a big family.

The responsive steering, composed handling, smooth ride and sweet six-speed gearbox make the Mondeo the ideal drive, whether you’re on a long motorway run or coping with city traffic.

This is why the model is such a hit with company car drivers who spend hours behind the wheel, making the car rather like a second home.

The other reason the Mondeo scores high is because of its low CO2 emissions. With 112 g/km, that reduces Benefit In Kind for 20 per cent tax payers to £539 and to £1,078 for 40 per cent tax payers.

Additionally, road tax is free for the first year and just £30 a year after that, while the excellent fuel economy means you can get close to 1,000 miles on a full tank.

The Mondeo’s virtues also include bags of room for five tall adults or parents with three kids, while the boot is a cavernous 528litres, increasing to 1,448 with the rear seats down – putting it on a par with a big estate.

Last, but by no means least, the Graphite’s price starts at a competitive £15,995, making it £2,000 cheaper than the previous entry Mondeo.

But if you want to really pamper yourself, go for the Titanium X Business Edition at £21,995 – that’s £1,500 cheaper than the Titanium X it replaces and it has more equipment.

So the good news is that the Mondeo remains a very good car and is now even better value. The bad news is that Americans are already driving an even better new version that won’t be available here for more than a year.

item.title: O-MG! Revival of a British icon
item.shortTitle: O-MG! Revival of a British icon
item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Motoring Editor
item.description: SUN Motors Ed gets an exclusive first drive of the MG3 in Shanghai
item.standfirst: SUN Motors Ed gets an exclusive first drive of the MG3 in Shanghai as Chinese bought 80,000 MGs last year — with just over 600 sold in UK

enclosure.caption: On show ... MG CS concept

item.tol-text:story:
CHINA has become the saviour of the global car industry.

It is now the most important car market in the world after racking up sales of more than 19MILLION last year.

That’s a staggering seven million more motors than were sold in Europe.

Last month alone two million vehicles were snapped up by car-hungry Chinese buyers — the same number of cars that were sold in the UK during 2012.

There are now more than 130 car manufacturers in China, with new ones being founded monthly.

Now the powerhouses of the motor world — America, Germany, South Korea, Japan and Britain — are all desperately trying to cash in on China’s love affair with the car.

Although the rate of growth has slowed for the first time in a decade, there is still huge potential for sales as the vast majority of the country’s 1.3BILLION inhabitants don’t have a motor.

Which is why China is also vital to thousands of British car workers who are pulling out all the stops to meet demand from the country.

And a famous British name, MG, is leading the British sales boom.

This week’s Shanghai International Motor Show is one of the most important events on the motoring calendar.

CHINESE motorists bought 80,000 MGs last year – compared to just over 600 here.

Life for the famous brand has changed dramatically since William Morris founded the firm back in 1924.

After the collapse of MG Rover in 2005, this most British of British car brands is slowly rising from the ashes — but is now very much a Chinese affair, owned by SAIC Motor Corporation, China’s largest car firm and the eighth biggest in the world.

SAIC sold 4.49million cars in 2012, more than double the entire UK car market for the same period.

The firm have invested millions in MG since they acquired the brand after MG Rover’s demise.

They have built a factory in Shanghai to make MGs and a £10million research and design centre to develop new models.

SAIC spokesman Zhu Xiangjun said: “We think MG is our long-term plan to become a global player. The potential is huge and we are happy with the progress it is making.”

The UK Research And Design Centre in Longbridge, Birmingham, employs just 300 people and may seem like an outpost. But it plays a key role in developing new models.

SAIC have invested more than £½billion in setting up their UK operation and gearing up the old Longbridge MG Rover factory to assemble MGs from kits shipped from China.

And despite their relatively small sales, MG are the jewel in SAIC’s motoring empire.

The firm have ambitious long-term plans to make their subsidiary a global player once again, with sales across Europe starting in 2015. MGs are already sold in 40 countries.

The Chinese firm’s obsession with the British brand was underlined at the Shanghai Show at the weekend. Models in Union Jack dresses and images of UK landmarks, plus pictures of the Queen, James Bond and Mr Bean flashed up on a big screen as the newest MG was unveiled.

Hundreds of Chinese and international journalists packed the MG stand to underline that the British brand still has an attraction to the car world.

And a dramatic new concept, the MG CS, the firm’s first SUV, showed the company are trying hard to change with the times.

MG say the CS is very close to a production version that will go on sale within two years in the UK and will rival models such as the Nissan Qashqai.

MG are also assessing whether to give the go-ahead for their radical Icon concept, a cross between a sports car and a coupé that recalls the classic MGB from certain angles.

One motor that will be going on sale in the UK later this year is the MG3 supermini, a car that is already proving a big hit with young Chinese customers.

One, Summer Zhuang, a 30-year-old marketing executive from Shanghai, has personalised her MG3 with a pink and white colour scheme.

She says the MG3 is seen as a motoring fashion statement in China and adds: “British car brands like MG, Bentley and Land Rover are seen as very trendy in China.

“I bought the MG because of its size and style. It’s perfect for driving in the city.”

MG’s UK sales and marketing director Guy Jones wants to repeat the MG3’s Chinese success with young British buyers.

He sees it going up against the Mini and Citroen DS3 as a small car with lots of personalisation.

He adds: “I see the MG3 appealing not only to traditional MG buyers but also attracting new, younger buyers to the brand.

“It’s a stylish small car with a distinctive cheeky style that’s also bigger than most superminis.”

Guy says the MG3’s other appeal will be its affordability when it goes on sale in the autumn, although he wouldn’t give official prices.

I expect it to start at around £10,000 and go up to £15,000.

This week I got an exclusive first drive of the MG3 in Shanghai and reckon it will be a contender in the supermini sector.

It has the styling to appeal to buyers of all ages, with an eye-catching face and sharp rear view. On the inside it has a smart, trendy feel, with touches of white trim finish. Plus it really does have good space for five tall adults plus a useful boot.

Its 1.5litre petrol engine is adequate but handles very well and has been tuned for British drivers at MG’s UK centre.

And if it’s priced between £10,000 and £15,000, it will attract new customers wanting something different and intrigued by the MG name, along with traditional fans still in love with the brand.

At the moment MG may seem like a token gesture in Britain, given their illustrious past and just 236 UK sales so far this year.

But I saw enough in China to believe they will once again be a force, though it will take time.

And what they’ve achieved already is remarkable, because despite the MG name and history, this is an entirely new car company being built from scratch.

item.title: I love UK! Chinese go mad for all things British
item.shortTitle: Chinese go mad for all things British
item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Motoring Editor
item.description: BIG sales in China play key role in keeping British car production lines rolling
item.standfirst: BIG sales in China are playing a key role in keeping British car production lines rolling – safeguarding 1000s of jobs

item.tol-text:story:
BIG sales in China are playing a key role in keeping British car production lines rolling – safeguarding many thousands of jobs.

Chinese consumers see famous British brands — like the MG and the iconic Mini — as a statement of their success, proof that they’ve “made it”.

With more than a million millionaires in China, the country has a host of potential customers for our premium/luxury car firms.

China is now the biggest sales market for Britain’s biggest car firm, Jaguar Land Rover, who are building a factory there to make up to 130,000 cars a year for Chinese buyers.

JLR have signed a joint venture with Chinese manufacturers Chery and they are together investing £1.8billion in a new factory that will start producing Land Rovers and Jags next year. They have already hired 400 workers.

Last year China became the biggest global market for JLR, with 71,940 cars sold. The firm set another record for China last month.

They now have 116 dealerships in China with plans to grow that to 163.

JLR unveiled both the new Range Rover Sport and the Jaguar F-Type at Shanghai — models guaranteed to boost sales to close to 100,000 this year.

JLR chief executive Ralf Speth said: “China is now JLR’s biggest market. Our commitment to the Chinese market is a business imperative.”

One in every four Rolls-Royce cars sold in the world are now bought by Chinese customers. And China is vying with the US to be their biggest single market.

Mega-rich Chinese customers see owning a Roller as the ultimate status symbol.

Chinese millionaires were putting down deposits for the firm’s new Wraith — despite a price tag of more than £500,000 — as soon as it was unveiled at Shanghai.

Chief executive Torsten Muller-Otvos said the reaction from potential buyers had exceeded expectations, adding that the firm were looking for further growth and expanding their dealer network in China.

And the Rolls boss exclusively revealed to The Sun that the next new model would be a convertible version of the Ghost.

“We would be crazy not to,” he admitted.

Aston Martin needed an army of security guards to control the crowds trying to see a special centenary edition of their new Rapide S model.

And several Chinese fans put down deposits for the Rapide S despite it costing upwards of £375,000 excluding taxes.

Boss Ulrich Bez says Aston expect a quarter of their sales to soon come from China, which is now their fastest-growing market.

Another famous luxury British brand enjoying booming sales in China is Bentley.

It’s now their second biggest market after America, with sales up 23 per cent last year.

It’s also the biggest single market for the Bentley Flying Spur, accounting for 50 per cent of global sales — which is why their stand was swamped with potential buyers for the new Spur.

Bentley’s boss Wolfgang Schreiber told The Sun: “China is a key market and we have significant expansion plans, including increasing our dealer network to 45 by 2015.”

item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Motoring Editor

item.standfirst: SUN CAMPAIGN: KEN Gibson starts pothole fight and challenges PM to spend a day with him on the roads of Britain

enclosure.caption: One hole of a disaster ... our broken roads

tol-text:ooyalaVideo.tol-text:headline: Ken Gibson's broken Britain road rage
tol-text:ooyalaVideo.tol-text:teaser: BRITISH drivers pay £46bn a year in motoring taxes for the worst roads in Europe

item.tol-text:story:
ROADS are the indispensable backbone of Britain.

But right now they’re crumbling into a minefield of potholes, disrepair and chaos.

These are the same roads British drivers pay £46billion a year in motoring taxes to use.

In return, the Government are investing just £6.3billion on major motorway and trunk road schemes and providing councils with around £3billion between 2011 and 2015 to maintain the roads.

Transport Minister Norman Baker says a highways maintenance efficiency programme has been set up to help local councils deliver a “first-class service, and at the same time save money”.

But Mr Baker must be driving on different roads to the rest of us if he thinks a first-class service is being delivered.

The reality is that the condition of many of our roads is what you’d expect in a Third World country rather than a powerhouse of Europe.

One in five local authority roads across England are reported to be in poor condition, with just five years’ life remaining.

The average road in England is fully re-surfaced just once every 54 years. And our vital motorway network is a sea of cones and daily disruption, with only nine major schemes planned for 2013/14 nationwide.

A new report has revealed it would take £10.5billion to get our roads back to just a “reasonable” condition.

The ALARM survey by road repair body the Asphalt Industry Alliance, which 75 per cent of local authorities responsible for roads in England and Wales participated in, says it would take 12 years to clear the backlog with adequate investment.

But the report concludes that with a yearly cash shortfall for maintenance work of £831million, our roads are just going to get worse.

The Government’s lack of investment is costing small and medium-sized businesses £5billion a year in wasted staff time, production delays, increased fuel consumption and vehicle repairs, according to research by pollsters YouGov.

And the Government paid £32million compensation to motorists last year for damage to vehicles because of the state of our roads, plus a further £13million to administer the payments.

The worst damage is to tyres, with an estimated 4.3million repairs last year, plus 2.9million cases of suspension damage and 2.4million wrecked wheels.

But this is just the tip of the iceberg as the majority of motorists don’t make claims.

Last year, local authorities filled in 2.2million potholes, but after a nightmare winter of bad weather that figure is set to get ever higher.

Geoff Dunning of the Road Haulage Association blames the Government’s false economy of stopgap repairs to our roads.

He says: “We are simply not repairing our roads properly.

“The Government need to invest more money on our roads and give our transport system the priority it deserves as the lifeline for British industry.”

Experts say filling potholes costs on average £58 each — which works out at least 20 times more expensive than resurfacing a whole road.

The Highways Agency are investing in some major schemes on motorways and trunk roads, along with “pinch-point programmes” that include widening schemes to remove traffic bottlenecks.

But many experts believe the money spent on patching roads up is actually making the problem worse.

The AA motoring organisation’s president Edmund King says that many of our roads are now a “national embarrassment”, especially considering the huge amount we pay in motoring taxes.

And Alan Mackenzie of the Asphalt Industry Alliance said: “The reality is that we are simply not investing enough in the maintenance of our roads.

“We need the Government to provide major additional investment in long-term preventative maintenance and not just short-term reactive work.”

And a quote from one local authority official in the recent ALARM survey sums up perfectly the crisis we are facing.

“The structural condition of our roads is a ticking timebomb.”

The irony is that if the Government are willing to invest heavily in serious maintenance and new road investment — like their obsession with the High Speed Rail link — it would create thousands of jobs and boost the economy.

The message is clear, Mr Cameron. It’s time for action not words.

Otherwise your legacy will be a broken-down road network that leads to nowhere.

Here's Ken's letter to David Cameron in full:

Dear Prime Minister,

This week I am giving you a challenge on behalf of the 35million motorists of the UK.

The challenge is that you spend a day with me driving the roads of Britain to experience first hand how they have become a national embarrassment.

British motorists now pay £46billion for the privilege of driving on some of the worst roads in Europe.

Of that just £8billion goes back into our roads, shared between motorways and local highways.

A major new report reveals that it would cost £10.5billion to get our road network back into just a “reasonable condition”, and that it will take 12 YEARS to clear the road repair back-log in England and Wales.

As there is currently a shortfall of £831million a year for highways repairs, there is not a hope in hell of our roads ever getting to a reasonable state.

Your Government are watching the disintegration of our road network, into a crumbling patchwork quilt of potholes and a sea of cones, because of totally inadequate funding in the roads.

And while our highways turn into the roads from hell your Government is pressing ahead with a multi-billion investment into a new rail link, while neglecting the roads that are the backbone of the economy.

Our roads are not only vital to industry but also support our daily lives.

It’s time the Government stopped using motorists as a cash cow and gave us a road network worthy of a country that’s meant to be one of the leaders in Europe.

An immediate way to put our roads back on track would be to invest a substantial amount of the £46billion you take from motorists in taxation directly back into the roads. I await your reply.

Yours Sincerely

Ken Gibson, Motoring Editor

item.tol-text:story:
THIS week we have a double bill of fast and faster, with a hot hatch and a red-hot sports car.

The Peugeot 208 GTi is the perfect illustration that you don’t need to be big to offer driving thrills. It may only have a 1.6litre turbo-charged engine, but it confirms hot hatches remain one of the more affordable ways of getting plenty of driving pleasure.

Any car carrying the Porsche badge guarantees the driver serious enjoyment and the new Cayman S is very worthy of that badge. Plenty of supercar buyers will pay triple the price of the Cayman but I bet they won’t get a lot more enjoyment. It is an exceptional car, hard to fault.

My road tests reveal these were two of the best drives I’ve had this year – I was gutted to hand back the keys.

ROAD TEST: PEUGEOT 208 GTi

ONE of the hardest tricks in the motoring book is to replace an icon.

Car firms know they are on a hiding to nothing — get it wrong and they will be slaughtered, get it right and it’s what people expected anyway.

And that is exactly the dilemma that Peugeot faced with the 208 GTi, the latest model to attempt to recapture the magic of the iconic 205 GTi of the 1980s.

Peugeot’s last two attempts, with the 206 and 207 GTi models, both ended in failure with cars that didn’t get close to the original. So there is big pressure on the 208 GTi, especially with very impressive new rivals in the Fiesta and Renault Clio.

But Peugeot did have a good base to start at. The standard 208 is a runaway success, with 300,000 sold in just a year, making it Europe’s best-selling supermini.

I’m old enough to remember the Eighties 205 GTi — a workmate owned one and I spent plenty of time in both the driver and passenger seat, so I can give a realistic assessment of the 208 in comparison.

Obviously, the 208 has the considerable advantage of nearly 30 years of continual advances in technology and design, which is also why it costs £18,895 compared to £6,295 for the 1981 205 GTi.

By hot hatch standards the 208 GTi actually looks a little understated, but I like the more restrained approach that gives the Peugeot a touch of extra class which you don’t expect from a pocket rocket.

The LED running lights, a chrome and matt black grille, deeper spoiler at the front and chrome wing mirrors still give it enough added attitude to stand out.

Bigger alloys, a rear roof spoiler and neat double exhaust pipes at the rear also add drama, but the best touch is the GTi logo cut in to the rear C pillar, just like the 205.

The interior definitely fits the image, with part-leather sports seats and a racy red, black and satin chrome colour scheme, with red trim around the main instruments, centre console and doors.

A small steering wheel that obscures the instruments, a chunky aluminium gear lever and matching pedals all leave you in no doubt that this is a hot supermini that comes with all the gadgets and connectivity apps via a seven-inch screen.

With the GTi Peugeot have rediscovered the fun factor in some style. The more time I spent throwing the GTi around mountain roads in France the bigger my smile became.

The 1.6litre turbo engine is a gem. Shared with the Mini Cooper S, it pumps out just short of 200bhp and delivers 0-62mph in 6.8 seconds and a top speed of 143mph.

At first, like the rest of the car, it sounds a little understated, with a low rumble of noise, but the quicker you go the sweeter the engine sounds, without ever becoming tiring. It’s the same with the steering — the faster you go, the more responsive it is.

Best of all, the ride retains a comfort level that you don’t expect from a hot hatch. The 208 GTi is a car you can drive on the limit or simply cruise around town. It’s happy in any road conditions and can switch to suit your driving mood, giving you sporty and refined in one package.

Prices start at £18,895, which is nearly £2,000 more than the entry-level Fiesta ST, but it has more equipment. Even so, satnav is £400 extra and with all the options the price can rise to £21,290, while the Renault goes from £18,995 to £19,995.

In truth the three cars are as close dynamically as they are in price and performance. If you want old-school rawness and the best price, go for the Ford.

If you want a grown-up hot hatch, the Renault fits the bill, but you get a less involving auto box instead of a manual.

But the classiest and best all-round package is the 208 GTi. It may lack the driving devil of the 205 GTi but it’s a thoroughly modern hot hatch that will be a lot more realistic to live with on a day-to-day basis.

ROAD TEST: PORSCHE CAYMAN S

THE 911 may be Porsche’s icon but the firm have a new star.

The Porsche Cayman has just been voted Performance Car Of The Year by a panel of World Car Of The Year judges.

I’m one of the World Car panel who voted for the Cayman ahead of Ferraris and the 911.

The reasons are numerous, but the most compelling is the sheer value for money the Cayman offers against any other sports car.

The price difference between a Porsche Cayman S at £48,783 and a 911 Carrera is a thumping £24,000. Go for the entry-level version and its £39,694 tag is an absolute bargain in sports car terms.

But the difference in performance and driving ability between the Cayman S and the 911 is so close, even a talented driver would struggle to make it truly noticeable.

It’s hardly surprising as they share the same brilliant 3.4litre flat-six engine that sees the Cayman S hit 62mph in 4.7 blistering seconds and on to 175mph.

There’s now a Sport mode as standard, which quickens the throttle response via the rapid six-speed manual gearbox, allowing you to wring the maximum performance and entertainment from the ever-willing engine.

The Cayman also shares the same amazing levels of grip and cornering of the Carrera but to me feels even more composed, and compared to the old model it feels less twitchy and less demanding to drive on long journeys.

Put together, it makes the Cayman one of the best cars in the world to drive. It’s a car that can lift you after a bad day at work like few others can.

The latest Cayman is 1½in longer at 14ft 4½in but its height drops by ½in, which gives it more road presence, along with a sharper new design.

That design is a classic Porsche example of subtle evolution, led by dazzling new twin LED headlights, wide, flared wheel arches and more pronounced rear wings, giving the Cayman striking proportions.

Its interior also steps things up. Not only does the extra length give you more space, especially shoulder room, but the quality of all the materials is now top-drawer.

I love the simple but beautifully laid out cabin that feels on a par with Porsches costing twice as much.

You don’t normally think of sports cars as things that give you real value for money, but the Cayman is the exception to the rule.

And that’s what makes it such an outstanding car — a car that is now at the top of its game and one of the best vehicles in the world.

Of course there will always be people happy to pay the extra cash for the extra clout of the 911 badge, but for me the Cayman S is now the best Porsche on the road.
