item.tol-text:story:
EVER wondered what 007 would drive if he settled down and became a family man?

Wonder no more. Aston Martin this week launched the sensational Rapide S, the world’s most beautiful four-seater sports car.

It’s also the perfect present for Aston Martin to celebrate their 100th anniversary this year.

Motors this week has a first drive of the Rapide S on UK roads – and an in-depth interview with the German boss who has transformed the famous British firm in the past decade.

THE BIG INTERVIEW

HE is the man who has done more for Aston Martin than James Bond.

For the past 13 years, Ulrich Bez has been the mastermind who turned Aston Martin from sporting pretender to the coolest car brand on the planet.

But the German engineer who learned his trade with Porsche and BMW admits: “I didn’t know anything about Aston when I arrived, I’d never even driven an Aston Martin car.”

He says he was attracted by the brand.

He says: “Aston Martin cars didn’t mean anything to me, but it was a brand I knew, like most people, because of James Bond.

“But I knew if we got the right products it could become a global brand that could challenge Ferrari.”

Bez also knew he was not everyone’s choice to be the boss and smiles when he remembers a senior executive openly questioning a German being in charge of the British brand.

But Bez has a reputation for not only being a brilliant engineer but also a perfectionist used to getting his own way and delivering great cars.

His impressive CV includes playing a key role in the development of the original BMW 3.5 and 7 Series, followed by the legendary 993 at Porsche.

But Aston was the first time Bez had total control of a car company, albeit reporting to their American owners of the time, Ford.

He found a company with a great name but just one sub-standard product, the DB7, and two factories — one a converted barn at Bloxham, Oxon, and the other a rundown facility at Newport Pagnell, Bucks.

Today Aston have a state-of-the-art factory at Gaydon, Warks, a line-up of glamorous models and instead of selling 600 cars a year they sell nearly 4,000.

Bez’s vision has also stretched to Aston’s first £1million-plus supercar, the 1-77, Aston’s first small car in the Cygnet, and their first four-door coupe, the Rapide.

The James Bond franchise and 007 himself has fallen back in love with Aston — Daniel Craig picked up his last month.

But it’s been a turbulent ride on the way. In his first week, Bez caused a strike when he banned workers at the Bloxham factory from eating beside the cars on the factory floor.

The strike was over in a week as the workers became the first to realise that Bez’s word was now law.

It was the first of many contentious decisions by Bez, all geared to his relentless drive for perfection and obsession with the quality he knew was needed.

Bez’s assessment after his first drive of the DB7 in 2000 was simple: “It was not up to my standards. I knew we had to immediately improve everything about the way we built our cars and their quality.”

His next decision was to postpone the launch of the Vanquish for a year because it wasn’t right.

Then he axed a planned mid-engined Aston and replaced it with the DB9 and the V8 Vantage.

But his biggest decision was to start a programme to develop a new body system that would allow Aston to make endless different models off the same chassis.

Bez also knew he had to give Aston a new, modern design identity to get them noticed again.

He says: “In 2000, no one apart from enthusiasts knew about Aston Martin outside the UK. We had to get a global visibility and I believed that every model had to instantly look like an Aston.”

He reveals that he would have liked a ground-breaking SUV model on the road by now. But he says the global recession of 2008 hit Aston and their Middle Eastern owners hard.

He says: “The economic situation slowed down the steps we wanted to take and put us back years.

“Of course I would like an Aston SUV, it is very important.”

Bez has a clear vision of the next five years, with a target of 7,000 sales a year based on the core sports models such as the DB9, Vanquish, Vantage and newly face-lifted Rapide S, plus hopefully an SUV.

Ironically, the most German of Germans, Ulrich Bez believes his biggest influence at Aston has been one thing.

He says: “Aston Martin now stands for the best of British and people love the firm because it’s British, and that is my biggest pleasure.”

At the age of 70, Bez is clearly not the long-term leader for Aston and he says he will be happy to hand over the reins.

He says: “If there is somebody with the personality, character and vision to be the front man for Aston, that is fine.”

They will have a mighty tough act to follow.

ROAD TEST: ASTON MARTIN RAPIDE S

I LIKE cars that live up to their name and the Rapide S does – big time.

The S stands for Sport, a commodity this car has by the bucket-load.

It also happens to be the most beautiful four-seater sports car in the world – but it now has a much more assertive face thanks to a gaping and menacing grille.

This sets the sporting tone for the Rapide S that is rounded off by an aggressive rear end, featuring a boot lid flip that counteracts lift at high speeds.

And high speed is what the new Rapide S has been built for – with power from the 6litre V12 engine boosted from 470bhp to 550bhp, cutting the 0 to 62mph time to 5.2 seconds and blasting the top speed up to 190mph.

The engine sounds sublime – a deep, glorious burble that explodes into a raging roar when you flatten the accelerator.

To complete the impressive figures, despite the extra power the Rapide S is more economical at 19.9mpg and CO2 emissions have been cut to 332g/km.

Engineers have also worked hard to improve the stability of the car at high speeds and a test drive in the Cotswolds underlined it was very much mission accomplished.

The Rapide S has a balance and agility that defy its 5,020mm length and it handles twisty, demanding country roads with the agility of a pure two-seat sports car.

Luxury Four people can do long journeys at well in excess of 100mph in silence, although the intimate back seats remain best for children or small adults because the S is not really a saloon car.

But anyone sitting inside the Rapide S will feel special as they are bathed in luxury with sports seats finished in a unique black and red interweaved perforated leather alongside carbon fibre and piano black trim.

In many ways, the new Rapide S is the perfect example of Ulrich Bez’s Aston Martin – a compelling mix of beauty, luxury and power with just a dash of four-seat practicality. All you need is £144,950 to buy one.

But the best news is that production of the Rapide S has been moved back to Gaydon, Warks, from Austria, making it very good news for British jobs.

item.tol-text:story:
THE Cat’s out the bag... and so is it’s Range Rover Sport stablemate.

Scotland will once again wow a global motor show next week when Jaguar unveil their most sensational limo yet in New York — the XJR, below.

The R is the work of Jag’s Dumfries-born head of design Ian Callum and his team and will be a star attraction in the Big Apple.

But the other big news is the LEAKED first picture of co-JLR star Range Rover Sport.

The Sport has been cloaked in secrecy before a big showbiz-style unveiling in New York next Wednesday.

But while the Sport was getting prepared for its launch, an employee, assigned to tint its windows, leaked the pictures online.

Land Rover bosses in the UK are currently investigating how the leak was allowed to happen but have confirmed that it will not affect their “spectacular” debut showpiece of the Sport on the streets of Manhatten will go ahead next week.

Range Rover are also promising a major A-lister will drive the new Sport for the launch, which will be broadcast online to a worldwide audience.

The new Sport will be the fastest ever Range Rover and finally live up to its athletic name. Prices are expected to start around £55,000.

Meanwhile, the Jag XJR will rival the Rangie for top billing.

The XJR boasts a stonking 542bhp supercharged 5litre V8. Jaguar have only released one picture, revealing a new bodykit, a set of bespoke alloys and some trademark R styling touches, such as the red Jaguar badge in the grille.

There are no performance figures yet but Jaguar are promising a bespoke chassis, with Adrian Hallmark, Global Brand Director at Jaguar claiming it will deliver “new levels of dynamic ability in a luxury saloon.”

The price is expected to be around £110,000.

item.tol-text:story:
RENAULT are back.

That’s the bold message employees are being told to use by new UK MD Ken Ramirez.

The Puerto Rican — who joined the firm in February after various roles in Latin America and Japan with sister firm Nissan — oozes positivity, and he needs it after a difficult year for the French giants.

In 2012 UK sales were down a whopping 40 PER CENT, to just under 41,000. Across Europe they slumped by six per cent. But Renault are on a mission to revitalise their brand after ruthlessly ditching loss-making models like Laguna, Espace and Wind.

The new era began with their most important car — the excellent new fourth-generation Clio — and we’ve just had a first drive of the equally-impressive Renaultsport versions.

Two of the next new models will be crossovers to rival Nissan’s Juke and Qashqai — beginning with the striking Captur revealed at the Geneva show last week.

Ramirez’s belief is backed by the new Clio, Captur and he wants to see Renault move “upmarket”. He also told me that the successful launch of the new Dacia budget brand will play a vital role in helping the French brand ditch sales of their models at significantly discounted prices.

Ramirez said: “We believe that Renault should be an aspirational brand and discounting undermines that policy.

“But that’s where Dacia plays a vital role. Every new Renault should be a car that people aspire to buy new — and are willing to pay a non-discounted price for. If you want a quality, low-price car, then buy a Dacia. If you want a mainstream quality offering, then buy a Renault.”

Ramirez also believes that, in the UK, the Clio and soon-to-arrive Captur illustrate how good Renault’s future can be.

He added: “In some markets Dacia has helped Renault enormously with sales volumes. But in the UK the fourth-generation Clio and Captur have arrived just in time to keep us a very strong brand.”

There is also a chance that Renault could look at a four-pronged sales assault with Dacia, Renault and then adding a sports brand like Alpine and premium division which echoes Inifiniti’s role at stablemates Nissan.

The Captur has success written all over it and is built on the same platform that underpins the Clio and hugely-successful Juke.

The petrol and diesel engine range will be carried over from the Clio, with the headline figure being a diesel which will return emissions of just 96g/km. It goes on sale in the UK in June priced from around £13,000.

Renault have also improved their Scenics. First up is the Scenic XMOD which is their compact MPV getting an SUV makeover. It still has the typically MPV-shaped body of the Scenic but now gets Renault’s new in-your-face family front end, incorporating the angled narrow grille and large Renault badge that graces the front of the new Clio.

Prices are expected to rise by £800 over the current Scenic MPV, which starts at £18,335. The Grand Scenic has also been tweaked and when it goes on sale later this year, prices are expected to remain close to the current £19,735.

Renault are also putting a family of electric models on sale this year, from the two-seat Twizy to a Kangoo electric van. But the vital one is the stunning Zoe supermini EV, with similar styling to the Clio, with prices starting from £13,600 after a £5,000 Government subsidy when it goes on sale this spring.

However, for now, it’s all about the impressive hot hatch Clios. Renault are definitely back... in fashion.

First Drive - New Renaultsport Clio 200

WHICH car firm has the most power on the Formula One grid? Would you guess Ferrari or Mercedes?

Unless you’re an F1 fan, I bet you didn’t think of Renault.

Kimi Raikkonen won the first grand prix of the year for Lotus, but it was a Renault engine that powered him. They also dominated the podium with third-placed Sebastian Vettel’s Red Bull also using French ooomph.

Surprisingly, it’s not widely known that Renault are the power behind FOUR Formula One teams — that’s one third of the grid — including world champs Red Bull, Lotus, Caterham and Williams. Not even giants Ferrari or Merc can boast that.

Ex-F1 world champ Raikkonen is actually the latest Renault advert star in their new Megane hatchback campaign, following in the iconic footsteps of Papa and Nicole and Va Va Voom.

They chose Raikkonen because Renault just got serious, they are determined to make more people aware of their racing expertise, technology and reliability.

The good news for us is that Renault’s F1 prowess just got affordable — from Formula One to one hell of a hot hatch. The 12million-selling Clio has undoubtedly been Renault’s heartbeat for 22 years. But the Renaultsport Clio is the car that gets your heart pumping.

I’ve just had a first drive in Granada, Spain, and the good news is that not only is the standard Clio back with a bang, but its wilder brothers have extra ooh la la.

Renault may have struggled for sales recently but they have an outstanding pedigree for hot hatches — selling more than 90,000 Clio Sports in 38 countries.

This new Clio 200 is a big departure from the current three-door 2litre-engined model as it is only available with a five-door body, 1.6litre turbocharged engine and EDC six-speed dual-clutch gearbox.

In plain English, that’s an auto not manual. It still comes in two chassis flavours — Sport and Cup. The latter aimed to cater for the trackday enthusiasts.

While the power is the same as the outgoing 2litre, torque and grip is up.

And, crucially, it’s lighter by 36kgs to make it more agile and give it extra performance, resulting in a rapid 0-62mph in 6.7 seconds and a top speed of 143mph. Economy also jumps up by 10mpg to 44mpg, while emissions fall 46g/km to 144g/km. But there’s one huge difference, the Clio Sport has lost its hardcore edge. Renault want to widen its appeal out of the niche track-day enthusiast market so they can nail more sales in the ever-growing hot hatch sector. That’s a huge risk on a car built on its track reputation. But Renault will accept upsetting boy racers for more buyers. Perhaps the biggest surprise is ditching the fun short-throw manual gearbox of the old RS with the auto double-clutch.

Renault claim the gears flick up in just 150 milliseconds but I found the changes too slow and frustrating even in Race mode. No manual box seems to have sucked all the true sporty essence out of driving and it doesn’t match the sharpness of VW’S equivalent DSG ‘box. But the best bit is that it is very quick.

The power is deep and meaningful from the minute you stamp your right foot, meaning you can really pull out of corners with pace.

It also sounds the business with a proper crackle and burble. You can even customise it to sound like other cars which is probably my favourite feature. It has a setting for a Renault futuristic machine with a spaceship noise. The Sport chassis handles with aplomb but lacks a sharp edge on cornering. That, again, may upset the connoisseurs but I preferred all the hardcore without the hard ride.

Renault will hope the Cup version will appease the track racers. I drove this for a few laps round the Guadix circuit and it felt the part. It’s firmer than its twin brother and far more aggressive but on this very smooth circuit it was hard to tell how it’ll cope with our horrendous potholes.The Renaultsport Clio also includes enough techno gizmos to keep an F1 garage geek happy. It boasts an R-Link system, which can be upgraded to include the RS Monitor — an on-board telemetry system which has a customisable display of engine parameters, performance data and a GPS-activated stopwatch for lap times. Mind-boggling stuff.

Not only does it perform, but it looks the dog’s danglies too. When I got behind the wheel of their Dezir concept two years ago, it was arguably the most beautiful car I’d ever driven. When Renault said the look would go into their next Clio, I laughed. Yet, remarkably, here it is. It’s been shrink-wrapped but the essence has been transformed from supercar to supermini and now hot hatch.

The interior matches the exterior for drama. Renault have added splashes of red for passion to punctuate the moody black interior which is a remarkable jump upmarket from the current car.The sophisticated dash from the standard car also goes up a notch with a black gloss centre console housing the 7in touchscreen with R-Link and integrated TomTom navigation with a chrome surround.

The new Renaultsport Clio is on sale now.

Even better news is that you don’t have to earn the money of an F1 driver to afford it, with it costing £18,995 — £100 more expensive that the forthcoming Peugeot 208 GTi. But it is a whopping two grand more than the albeit less-powerful Ford Fiesta ST.

A Renault engine topped the lot in the F1 at the weekend. It might be a bit softer round the edges, but on the ultra-tough hot hatch grid, this Clio is also back in pole position.

tol-text:ooyalaVideo.tol-text:headline: Sun Motors checks out the Vauxhall Cascada
tol-text:ooyalaVideo.tol-text:teaser: THE most stylish Vauxhall in years is a well-sculpted, muscular, full four-seat convertible and it's not too pricey

item.tol-text:story:
VAUXHALL have been injecting a serious dose of styling into their cars in the past few years.

It all started with the Insignia, followed by the Astra, Zafira and more recently the funky Adam and Mokka.

But the Vauxhall that’s set to turn heads is the Cascada, a four-seat convertible that looks as toned as Jess Ennis in Lycra.

Like Jess, the Cascada has a well-sculpted, muscular body. The only thing that didn’t look fresh was the predictable chrome grille that sits on all Vauxhalls and is beginning to look dated.

But does the Vauxhall have the image to make a statement in the world of convertibles, where premium brands dominate and badge snobbery counts?

Vauxhall point out that the Cascada is nearly £8,000 less than the slightly smaller Audi A5 convertible, but the Audi is very big on image.

But judge the Cascada on merit alone, whether on style, quality or engineering capabilities and it stands favourable comparison — and a starting price of £23,995 is not big money for a mid-sized four-seat soft-top.

I drove the Cascada for nearly 400 miles over two days in dry and wet conditions on city streets, motorways and twisting mountain roads.

It was a relaxing, stress-free and enjoyable experience, which marked out the Cascada as a convertible that is a useable everyday car and a genuine four-seater.

Don’t think of it as a replacement for the Astra TwinTop convertible — it’s an altogether more classy affair and considerably bigger at 4,696mm. And don’t think of the Cascada as a sports car — it is very much a grand tourer convertible with the ability to transport four people in comfort, whatever the British weather throws at you.

If the sun shines, the electric fabric roof can be down in just 17 seconds at speeds up to 30mph. Just as importantly, it goes up in the same time and at the same speed so you can avoid being soaked in a sudden shower.

And the high-quality hood with an extra layer of polyester fleece insulation makes the Cascada as quiet as hard-top coupe, even at high speeds. What is probably most impressive about the Cascada is the quality of the interior, which doesn’t look out of place against top-notch German opposition.

Even the entry-level SE model in fabric trim is well finished with hand-stitched leather on the dashboard, alongside instruments with the detail of a fine watch.

Move up to the Elite model and you get high-quality soft leather heated seats front and back and all the toys and gadgets that you’d expect on any Audi or BMW.

There’s everything from satnav and cruise control and a high-grade music entertainment system to safety equipment such as lane assist. The Cascada is also practical by convertible standards, with 380litres of boot space with the roof up and 280litres with the roof down.

And the rear seats fold flat, allowing longer objects such as snowboards or surfboards for couples who enjoy sports.

The Cascada also benefits from getting two of Vauxhall’s latest engines, stretching from a 1.4litre turbo petrol to a 2litre bi-turbo diesel that delivers 54mpg.

I was most impressed by the new 1.6litre petrol, which delivered a nice mix of performance — 0-62mph in 9.2 seconds, a top speed of 135mph and just under 40mpg.

The crisp handling and responsive steering mean the Cascada has the agility to make a mountain drive good fun with the roof down and easy to drive in city traffic or on long motorway trips.

There is an argument that the world doesn’t need another convertible but I think Vauxhall have done a brilliant job making the Cascada a genuinely desirable and affordable one.

Vauxhall are looking to sell more than 2,000 a year in the UK — and with prices ranging from £23,995 to £28,605, that target should be more than achievable.

item.tol-text:story:
THERE was something for everyone produced in Britain at Geneva – from the £10,000 Nissan Note to the £265,000 Rolls-Royce Silver Wraith.

But the most spectacular British debut at the show was the £886,000 McLaren P1, a car being billed as a “hybrid hypercar” — a green supercar.

The fearsome and fabulous-looking P1 is the 217mph successor to the legendary F1 that was the world’s fastest car when launched in 1999.

The P1 is powered by a combination of a 727bhp, 3.8litre twin turbo V8 engine and a 176bhp electric motor. That’s a total of 903bhp that delivers 0.62mph in 2.8 seconds.

McLaren say their aim is not to be the fastest but the easiest to drive the faster you go. The P1 will also do 12 miles on pure electric power making it a supercar with zero emissions in the city.

The aim of the Silver Wraith Coupé is to provide high-performance in the ultimate pampered luxury.

It’s not only the most powerful Roller ever — 0-60mph in 4.4seconds — but also the most stylish.

The firm have almost sold out the first year’s supply. It has also created 100 jobs at the firm’s Goodwood HQ.

Bentley’s new Flying Spur offers 200mph supercar speed in a four-seat saloon that is like a mobile stately home.

Priced at £140,900, the Spur is almost a bargain by luxury limo standards.

Britain’s hat-trick of luxury four-seat high-performance cars is joined by the new Aston Martin Rapide S which proves the world is going power crazy.

Aston’s four door gets a bold and deep grille that gives the front end a more ballsy look.

But the big change is under the bonnet where the 6litre V12 gets a power boost from 470 to 550bhp, reducing 0-62mph to five seconds and taking the top speed to 190mph.

At £150,000, the Rapide S is an early present to celebrate Aston’s 100th anniversary this year. It may not be the most comfortable four seater but it is, by some distance, the most stylish.

So that’s your lottery winnings spent. What about back in the real world? Easy — check out the new version of the Nissan Note which has gone from interesting mini people carrier to sharp looking supermini.

Nissan are aiming the Note firmly at the UK’s best-selling car, the Fiesta, which is a tough ask but the Note is an altogether more stylish proposition than the model it replaces, inside and out.

Alongside the Note was a face-lifted version of the all-electric Leaf that has increased its range to a maximum of 124 miles (up from 109) and the price has been reduced to £23,000, including a Government grant of £5,000.

Both the Leaf and the Note will be built at Nissan’s Sunderland factory, creating hundreds of new jobs this year.

Toyota showed their Auris Sports Tourer estate car, which is further evidence of the firm’s promise to make models with more emotional appeal to go with reliability.

It will be built alongside the Auris hatchback in Derbyshire and its extra practicality, with 1,658litres of space with the seats down, should see no shortage of family buyers.

It’s on sale now with prices from £15,595 up to £21,095 for the 1.8litre petrol hybrid.

Honda have also come up with a racy looking estate version of the Swindon-built Civic, that adds a new dimension to the Civic range. It will go on sale at the end of the year from around £16,000.

If the Jaguar F-Type and Range Rover Evoque have been seen many times before, they were still two of the most important cars at the show.

The Range Rover is already off to a flying start with waiting lists in some countries, and the F-Type roadster has attracted huge interest around the world and will be one of the year’s must-have motors when it goes on sale next month.

Holding its own for glamour against any of the big boys was the striking 4-seat Vauxhall Cascada convertible at £23,995.

item.standfirst: VOLKSWAGEN’S XL1 diesel-electric hybrid looks like a spacecraft and its fuel economy is out of this world

enclosure.caption: Aerodynamic ... Volkswagen's XL1 diesel-electric hybrid
Winging it ... our Ken at the wheel of XL1
Sleek ... it’s super-light

item.tol-text:story:
IT looks like a spacecraft and its fuel economy is out of this world — meet the 313mpg car.

Volkswagen’s XL1 diesel-electric hybrid could get you from London to Leeds on £4 of fuel.

The 800cc engine can take this aerodynamic motor from 0-62mph in 11.9 seconds and the top speed is 99mph.

Volkswagen has spent £1BILLION over 15 years to make it as light as possible to improve fuel economy. The body is carbon fibre reinforced plastic and the windscreen is the world’s thinnest.

The suspension is made of lightweight aluminium and the tank holds just ten litres.

The two-seater XL1, which can do 30 miles on electric, weighs in at 800kg — 400kg less than an average small family motor.

An average car of the same size does 45mpg.

It feels a bit like a cross between a sports car because you sit low, and a super-mini because it’s so easy to handle. VW plans to make just 250 to lease at £500 a month — the same as renting a VW Passat.

But Dr Ulrich Hackenberg, VW’s head of Research and Development, says the technology will appear in mainstream models in five years.

So you could be driving a 313mpg VW Golf by 2018 for a few thousand pounds more than its current £16,000 price.

item.title: The supercars that changed the world
item.shortTitle: Meet the top ten best cars ever
item.author: By TOM EDWARDS
item.description: HOW does the latest Lamborghini compare with the greatest cars ever to be built?
item.standfirst: LAMBORGHINI announced the release of their latest supercar this week, but how does it compare to the greatest ever?

enclosure.caption: Brand new ... the Lamborghini Veneno
Best ever ... the iconic McLaren F1
Fastest on the planet ... Bugatti Veyron
Classic ... Ferrari F40
Shaken, not steered ... James Bond's famous Aston Martin DB5
Pioneer ... Lamborghini Countach
Ahead of its time ... Dusenberg model SSJ
Inspiration ... Ford GT40
Richly rewarding ... millionaire's favourite Pagani Zonda
Iconic ... Porsche 911
Blue-min hell ... Shelby Cobra is a beast of a car

item.tol-text:story:
LAMBORGHINI announced the release of their stunning new supercar, the Veneno, this week.

With a 750 horsepower engine that can top speeds of 220mph, they claim it’s the fastest, most powerful supercar they’ve ever built.

And at a cool £3million, it certainly has the price tag to match.

But how does the Veneno compare to history’s greatest monster motors?

Here we take a look at the top ten supercars ever made to find out.



1. MacLaren F1

No list of supercars would be complete without the F1.

Starting life in 1991, the Brit-built vehicle went on to break numerous speed records and revolutionise car design around the world.

Production ended in 1998 with only 106 cars ever being made.



2. Bugatti Veyron

The super sport Veyron is the fastest street-legal car on the planet with a top speed of 267mph.

It features a massive 8-litre turbo engine that kicks out a frankly ridiculous 987 brake horsepower.

It was also recognised by Sun columnist Jeremy Clarkson as the car of the decade for 2000-2009 on Top Gear.



3. Ferrari F40

When the F40 was released in 1987, it was the fastest and most powerful car Ferrari sold.

It was also the most expensive — some buyers are reported to have paid an eye-watering $1.6MILLION to get their hands on one.

It is still recognised as one of the best supercars around to this day.



4. Aston Martin DB5

The DB5 is technically a grand tourer, rather than a supercar, but James Bond’s most famous motor is so iconic it was impossible to leave it out.

The real thing doesn’t have machine guns or ejector seats, but it is still recognised as one of the most beautiful vehicles ever made.



5. Lamborghini Countach

The countach was a pioneer in more ways than one.

It was the first to make the aerodynamic “wedge-shaped” design popular and it was also the first supercar to move the driver’s cabin forward, leaving more space in the back for its phenomenal engine.

Experts regularly cite the Countach as a real breakthrough in supercar design.



6. Dusenberg model SSJ

Compared to today’s mega-powerful motors, the Dusenberg’s paltry 350 horsepower might not sound like much.

But when you consider the model SSJ was hitting those heights in the 1930s, the picture starts to look at bit different.

This car was way ahead of its time, managing to achieve a top speed of over 135mph in 1935.

One of them sold at auction in 2004 for $4.4MILLION — making it one of the world’s most expensive cars.



7. Ford GT40

This iconic racer took the world by storm when it won the “24 Hours of Le Mans” race four consecutive times in the 1960s.

Since then it has been admired by petrol-heads the world over.

The GT40 was also used as the inspiration for the Ford GT, released in 2005.



8. Pagani Zonda

Famous for being a millionaire’s plaything, the Zonda is adored by Top Gear presenter Richard Hammond.

It can hit speeds of over 230mph and debuted in 1999.



9. Porsche 911

Perhaps more well known for its iconic shape than for stats and specs, the 911 is still one of the greatest cars ever made.

Porsche have released various incarnations of the model over the years, one of which — the 935 turbo — won 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1979.



10. Shelby Cobra

One of these amazing 800-horsepower beasts made history in 2007 when it sold at auction for $5.5million.

Known as the “super snake” the car was built in 1966 and is as beautiful as it is expensive.



Verdict: While the new Lambo may have some impressive stats, these classic supercars have been tried and tested for years - they have earned their place at the top.

It's going to take some time before we really know if the Veneno can put its mouth where its money is.

tom.edwards@the-sun.co.uk

item.tol-text:story:
SAN Francisco sunshine, the world’s fastest four-seat convertible and a 1,000 mile drive... perfect.

Especially when you’ve just left England in the grip of an icy Arctic freeze.

And my trip in the Bentley Continental GT Speed turned into a dream drive from San Francisco to Las Vegas in two glorious days of high-speed driving — roof down the whole way.

America is actually the ideal location for a Bentley — and not just because of the weather.

It’s the biggest sales market for the luxury brand and the GT convertible.

Mind you, Bentley are currently enjoying sales success across the world, as the British firm have once again established themselves as one of the favourite brands for the rich and famous.

And when you see the GT Speed convertible glistening in the early-morning sunshine, it’s easy to see why.

There may be more exotic convertibles than the Bentley but none can match its aristocratic grandeur.

It’s the perfect mix of high-speed performance and unashamed luxury — a mobile testament to British craftsmanship at its very best.

It has to be the classiest way to get a sun tan — albeit a seriously expensive one as it carries a price tag of £167,900.

The GT Speed also happens to be the fastest way to experience wind-in-the-hair motoring for four people, living up to its name with a top marker of 202mph.

Floor the accelerator pedal and you are propelled forward in a wave of power. Forget about 0-60mph times — the GT Speed hits 100mph in just 9.7 seconds and continues relentlessly until you join the 200mph club.

It should feel like a violent punch in the back but this is a Bentley and it does all the hard work in a ridiculously smooth and serene manner.

Clearly they are excessive speeds that will lose you your licence and the reality is you won’t drive anywhere near the top speed in the UK.

But knowing the Bentley can do it is part of what makes it so special. What you will do constantly is flatten the accelerator pedal just so you can hear the velvety sound of the 6litre W12 cylinder engine.

In full cry, it is a motoring masterpiece — a deep rumble that erupts like a volcano.

There are other elements that take the driving experience to an added dimension of pure pleasure.

Things such as the brilliant eight-speed auto gearbox, which can switch to manual mode via F1-style paddles on the steering column or a beautifully crafted aluminium gearlever. The way the Bentley handles at speed is also truly remarkable, even more so when you think how big it is.

The grip at times seems to defy the laws of physics and it’s capable of doing it in any conditions — as I experienced in the snow-capped mountains of Nevada — because the GT Speed is equipped with all-wheel drive.

Lowered and self-levelling sports suspension that adapts instantly to the road also gives the GT a magic carpet ride at speeds which would see most cars careering off the road.

I could happily spend the rest of my driving days sitting in the glorious luxury of the Bentley, because this is British craftsmanship in wood and leather that no one can equal.

You can see, touch and feel the hours of painstaking expertise that have gone into crafting the Bentley cabin — the intricate hand-stitching of the leather work and wood that has been lovingly shaped like sculpted furniture.

And it’s the wonderful extras, such as the neck warmer fitted into the heated seats, that allow you to drive roof-down all year round. (The leather quilted seats can also massage you and be cooled in summer.)

Should you tire of the engine sound, there is a music and entertainment system that’s like having front-row seats at the Royal Albert Hall.

I also love the understated elegance of the GT Speed — the sculpted bodywork that ripples like the finely tuned muscles of an athlete.

The classic Bentley grille is finished in a subtle dark tint, while the twin LED headlights sparkle like jewellery and the 21in alloys look like a modern chariot’s wheels.

It’s all nicely finished off by an XL-sized double exhaust and a rear diffuser that, like the rest of the GT Speed, hints at something extra special.

Which is exactly what it is — a showpiece of British craftsmanship and engineering excellence for lucky owners with the need for speed.

item.title: Czech for 15 million

item.author: By KEN GIBSON, Motoring Editor
item.description: KEN Gibson test drives the Skoda Octavia
item.standfirst: SKODA are celebrating producing 15 million cars, and here Ken Gibson test drives the latest Octavia

enclosure.caption: Skoing mental ... 15 millions Skodas made so far
Back in front ... Skoda is a bargain
Trim ... soft-touch plastic or leather in top-range cars
Spacious ... enough room for four tall adults

item.tol-text:story:
IT’S still not exactly cool to buy a Skoda – but it’s becoming an increasingly smart move to own one.

Skoda are celebrating producing 15million cars, with five million built in the last six years.

And in 2012 they had yet another record car sales year, shifting almost a MILLION – a massive transformation from the early 1990s when they sold 172,000 Favorits a year.

Like in the rest of Europe, UK drivers are now big fans of Skoda and the reason is simple – you get an awful lot of car for your money.

Their 15millionth car is impressive but the real story is that one third of those vehicles have been made in the past six years.

Skoda have deservedly become one of the major motoring success stories of the last decade — almost a rags-to-riches story.

If Skoda were not quite in rags when the Volkswagen Group took control in 1991, they were one of the car world’s poor relations.

Obviously the VW Group have played a key part in the firm’s transformation, having invested millions in new models and facilities and sharing state-of-the-art technology.

But Skoda are still run from their homeland in the Czech Republic, with highly skilled workers continuing a car-making tradition that spans 118 years.

That makes Skoda one of the oldest car manufacturers in the world.

Proud Company chairman Dr Winfried Vahland explained: “The Skoda team is very proud of reaching 15 million cars — it is a symbol of the great development of the brand.”

And it was very fitting that the 15th millionth model produced was a new Octavia — the model that has been the heartbeat of the firm’s turnaround with 3.75million sales since 1996, including 210,000 in the UK.

Below we have tested two of the new versions.

ROAD TEST: SKODA OCTAVIA

THE new Octavia was proving a seriously impressive car... until it refused to start.

The failure was a major shock for a car noted for its reliability, and an embarrassment — because it happened when I was giving some friends a lift to a funeral!

The excellent man from the AA who quickly got me moving said there was an electrical glitch that had drained the battery.

He also said that such faults occasionally happened on just about every car because of the huge amount of technology in modern vehicles.

So I’m happy to give the Octavia the benefit of the doubt and put it down to a rare gremlin, because the car and a second model were excellent — and I’ve never had a problem with a Skoda in over 20 years of testing.

The latest Octavia is quite simply better than the model it replaces in every way.

Quality It’s bigger, better quality and although it competes against hatchbacks in price, it’s the size of a big family car.

Although it shares its body platform with the latest VW Golf, it has an extended wheelbase that makes it 90mm longer and 45mm wider.

This means it’s got executive car interior space for four or five tall adults, and the boot is huge.

At 590 litres, it’s bigger than a Mondeo’s, and increases to 1,580 litres with the rear seats down. That’s big estate territory.

And driver and passengers travel not only in comfort but also in style, with quality soft-touch plastics and trim and plush leather in the top-of-the-range models.

Even the entry-level model gets air con, a DAB radio and Bluetooth connectivity, electric front windows, heated door mirrors, central locking and an outside temperature gauge. You can add sat-nav for £550.

Stepping up to the SE trim adds rear parking sensors, dual zone climate control and alloys, while the range-topping Elegance gets sat-nav, leather upholstery and cruise control.

The Octavia is now an imposing looking car with a strong, elegant profile that gives it an upmarket appearance.

It’s the same story on the inside where everything from the smart instrument dials and trim make this a Skoda with a VW Passat feel about it.

And as the Octavia shares the full VW line-up of top notch petrol and diesel engines, the driving package is top drawer as well.

The old entry level 1.4 has been replaced by an excellent 1.2litre TSi petrol, used by Audi.

This is a gem, more than capable of pulling the extra bulk of the Octavia in a smooth and refined way, plus nearly 50mpg.

But if you want more power, there are other petrol options on the TSi, up to 2litres, that deliver between 37 and 44mpg.

And if economy is your aim, the 1.6 and 2litre diesels are good for between 58 and 62mpg.

Handling and ride are also good which means as an all-round package, the Octavia is hard to beat.

Though it’s about £2,000 more than the model it replaces, the reality is the Octavia has been superseded by the new Rapid model and is now competing with models in the class above.

Which means that the starting price of £15,990 for the entry 1.2litre TSi is a real bargain for a car that offers so much.

And at £23,240 even the top-of- the-range 2litre turbo diesel Octavia in full leather makes plenty of sense.

Compare that to £7,500 for the cheap, nasty and considerably smaller Favorit in 1991 and today’s Skodas look every inch a bargain.

item.title: Audi kick RS with the new Q3 SUV
item.shortTitle: Audi aiming to kick RS with the new Q3 SUV
item.author: By PHIL LANNING
item.description: AUDI get ready to step up their charge to become the world’s No1 premium firm
item.standfirst: AUDI could be ready to step up their charge to become the world’s No1 premium firm by DOUBLING their SUV models

enclosure.caption: Fast ... Audi is quick and makes incredible noise

item.tol-text:story:
AUDI could be ready to step up their charge to become the world’s No1 premium firm by DOUBLING their SUV models.

The German giants released first pictures of the new Q3 RS this week, their first SUV to wear the RS badge.

But the big news is that they are ready to launch a Q2, Q4 and Q6 over the next few years as they believe that will help them topple BMW as the world’s top prestige sellers.

Audi only moved into SUVs in 2005 with the Q7 and subsequently added the Q5 and Q3.

The SUV market is one of the fast-growing sectors in the world and is expected to expand from 2.2million sales last year to 3million within the next five years.

After increasing sales 12 per cent to 1.46million cars last year, Audi’s performance is also driving parent firm Volkswagen’s equally ruthless bid to become the world’s No1-selling car firm by 2018.

The Q3 RS is the fourth performance division model that Audi will launch this year alongside the RS6 Avant, RS5 Cabriolet and RS7.

It’s powered by a 2.5litre turbocharged petrol engine and can hit 62mph in just 5.5 seconds and hit an electronically limited top speed of 155mph. The Q3 RS is expected to cost a whopping £11,000 more than the current Q3 2litre at around £42,000.

But, with those sort of performance figures, that’s an SUV that belongs on the Nurburgring.

And we did just that with Audi’s mouthwatering new RS4 Avant.

We drove this great estate to Germany and also this week had a first drive in Scotland. For this generation, the RS4 is only available as an Avant — Audi say buyers of the old saloon and cabrio versions have switched to the RS5.

We reckon that’s a good thing — the Avant body boasts 1,430 litres of space and it looks breathtaking in RS spec. There are big air intakes in the aggressive front bumper, bulging squared-off wheelarches, 19in alloys and a rear end that features huge chrome exhausts and a roof spoiler.

Engineers have also dropped the ride height by 20mm and fitted uprated brakes. You can also add ceramic brakes and the £2,250 Sport Package, which includes Dynamic Ride Control adaptive dampers, dynamic steering, 20in alloys and a sports exhaust.

It’s got amazing kit and it also goes like s***. Up front is an RS5-derived 444bhp 4.2litre V8, which drives all four wheels through a seven-speed twin-clutch S tronic gearbox.

The RS4 Avant is incredibly fast. With launch control system, it sprints from 0-62mph in just 4.7 seconds — just a tenth down on its closest rival, the 451bhp Mercedes C63 AMG Estate. The 4.2litre engine is phenomenal in its response. It really is supercar fast, while the noise it makes is incredible — a sensational V8 rumble, which is punctuated by pops and bangs from the exhaust when you lift off.

But the RS4’s real attraction is the traction.

Even on our icy and greasy potholed roads, the benefit of the quattro four-wheel-drive system and the clever electronic aids make sure all the power is distributed to whatever tyres have the most grip and all the power is translated into forward acceleration.

It’s also quite comfortable. Audis can be hard-riding, but once in Comfort suspension mode, this RS4 delivers all the breathtaking without being back-breaking.

There’s no shortage of standard equipment, either. You get sports seats and a DVD sat-nav.

It’s not cheap at £54,925. But remember this is a car that’s good for racing at the ‘Ring just as well as the rubbish dump.

This is another Audi winner. They’re going all out to kick their rivals up the RS.

item.standfirst: HERE is Scotland’s perfect mix of ice cream and ice cool. This is the sensational Ferrari FF

enclosure.caption: Fine Ferrari ... our Phil with latest Italian supercar

tol-text:ooyalaVideo.tol-text:headline: Phil Lanning takes the new Ferrari FF for a spin
tol-text:ooyalaVideo.tol-text:teaser: SCOTTISH Sun Motors Editor takes the latest offering from the prancing horse to the west coast of Scotland

tol-text:enclosure.caption: SCOTTISH Motors Editor takes the latest offering from the prancing horse to the west coast of Scotland

item.tol-text:story:
IT’S Scotland’s perfect mix of ice cream and ice cool.

This is the sensational Ferrari FF — the four-wheel-drive supercar that can still deliver all the go, go, go even in the snow.

For once Scotland’s weather didn’t let us down, serving up a blanket of the cold white stuff to help prove what this FF can really do.

Bizarrely, the snow had melted on the way down to Ferrari’s Scottish ‘Little Italy’ spiritual home in Largs, Ayrshire.

This is where the world’s most famous and powerful brand meets the home of Scotland’s most famous cafe and ice cream parlour, Nardinis, and restaurant, Tony Macaroni.

The Nardini family arrived in Scotland in 1890 but this café opened in 1935 — the same year Enzo Ferrari and engineer Luigi Bazzi developed the Alfa Romeo Bimotore racing car.

It was the first ever car to carry the now famous prancing horse Scuderia Ferrari on its flanks — and has been dubbed the first ever Ferrari.

And ever since 1935, this seafront corner has oozed more Azzurri than Ayrshire.

Largs is also the home of Colin and Chris Weir, the UK’s biggest-ever lottery winners of £161million back in July 2011.

Indeed, you’ll need to hit the lotto jackpot to afford this FF at £227,000.

But this is something very special. It could be phew.

On paper it just doesn’t sound right — a four-seat Ferrari 4x4.

But the world’s favourite supercar firm turned the motoring world upside down with this shock merchant.

Driving the Ferrari is a breathtaking and unforgettable experience, whether you are on snow or Tarmac.

This is the Ferrari for all seasons. The highly talented engineers have clearly relished the challenge of developing an all-wheel-drive system, in the same way they enjoy bringing the technology of the racetrack to their road-going supercars.

How the system works is a seriously complex affair — you need to be Stephen Hawking to understand it.

All you really need to know is that it works brilliantly and gives the FF phenomenal grip in all conditions.

Unlike the permanent heavyweight all-wheel-drive systems on the average 4x4, the sophisticated Ferrari package is half the weight and only operates grip on all four wheels when it is necessary. But, being a Ferrari, having a hi-tech 4x4 system would be irrelevant if the FF couldn’t also perform with the firm’s legendary handling and performance.

The latest version of the 6.3litre V12 engine hits 0-62mph in just 3.7 seconds, 0-125mph in 11 seconds and a top speed of 208mph. That guarantees it instant access to the supercar elite.

Even the fuel economy is a reasonable 19mpg and CO2 is down to 360g/km.

Climbing into the cockpit feels like being planted into the soul of supercars.

You are greeted by a steering wheel that looks more PlayStation than Prancing Horse. All the controls are on this wheel.

One firm press on the most important ‘Start’ button and there is a brief delay.

Then all hell breaks loose. The ignition kicks in with a ripping crackle that goes up through your feet, spleen, spine and into your eardrums and dreams. It’s pure horsepower with a huge dash of Hollywood.

The steering is ultra-responsive and pin sharp, while the F1-style paddles deliver razor-sharp gear changes from the seven-speed gearbox.

There is also the Manettino control panel, which has settings for comfort, sport, wet, ice/snow and an electronic stability control. This means you can dial in the setting to suit the conditions — or your mood.

There is even a launch control button for instant lift-off.

But the FF’s final trick is to allow four people to enjoy the amazing Ferrari experience and in a degree of comfort. In the back, I had good leg and head room and even my 6ft 3in nephew fitted in snugly.

The luggage space is also remarkable for a supercar — 450litres. That is enough for golf bags and luggage cases.

With the rear seats folded flat, it increases to 800litres. That is close to estate-car levels of versatility.

All this is packaged in first-class levels of luxury, from the figure-hugging soft leather seats to the extensive executive equipment like satnav and entertainment system with rear-seat DVD players.

Despite a price tag of £227,000, the FF has been a big sell-out — and exclusivity guaranteed with less than 50 coming to the UK.

In this meeting of Nardinis ice cream of North Ayrshire and sheer power, these legendary Italians certainly know how to serve up something ultra cool — whether FF stands for four-wheel-drive or fast food.

One thing is for sure, though, this Ferrari is simply phenomenal with a capital FF.

item.tol-text:story:
BUILDER and TV star Tommy Walsh wants a vehicle that’s tough and hard working but stylish too.

That’s why he was delighted to test drive the SsangYong Korando Sports 4x4 pick-up.

As a busy dad-of-three, juggling his building firm in east London with work as a writer and telly presenter, Tommy is after a motor that delivers on several fronts.

Which is why he loved the versatility of the Korean brand’s 4x4 pick-up.

Tommy, 56, said: “For a builder or a tradesman, a utility vehicle has to do what it says on the tin and the Korando Sports does.

“But the bonus is it’s also nice-looking and comfortable. You can more or less get any tools you need into the back.

“The tailgate is strong and heavy so you can use it as an extension if you’ve got a longer load.

“And if you need height, the weather-proof canopy comes off the rear loading bay.

“But the top is good for security and that’s important as most tradesmen carry a lot of valuable kit these days.

“The Korando Sports doubles up great as a domestic vehicle. It looks good and the leather interior is stylish and easy to wipe clean.

“But the real winner was the heated seats. My wife Marie loved them and so did my 19-year-old son Jonjo after football training.

“And for a builder, full of aches and pains after a tough day, it’s like having a hot massage as you drive home. What a clever thing to put into a working vehicle.”

The Sports is a powerful beast, too, with a braked-trailer limit of 2.3 metric tonnes.

Tommy said: “It feels like a big car, secure and robust, but it’s nifty and has a good turn of speed and the engine is surprisingly quiet.

"There’s good vision all round and it’s fitted with parking sensors, which is great for a big vehicle.

“The cabin is spacious too — I’m a big bloke and I found it very comfortable.

“I particularly thought the Bluetooth for your phone was a bonus. Hands-free is so important for a tradesman as your livelihood can depend on being able to take calls while you’re on the move.

“And you certainly get a lot of bang for your buck. I’ve only used a quarter of a tank of diesel and I’ve been all over in it for five days.

“The three key things a tradesman looks for are: Is it right for the job? What is the price? And what is the mpg?

“And the five-year unlimited mileage warranty is absolutely brilliant — a really reassuring extra.”

tol-text:enclosure.caption: KEN Gibson get a chance to ride in the latest offering from the big cats stable. Will it live up to all the hype?

item.tol-text:story:
THE stakes couldn’t be any higher for one single car...

If Jaguar are to regain their status as one of the world’s great car brands, the new F-Type has to be a 100 per cent sales success.

Failure is not an option and the F-Type can’t simply be very good. It needs to be outstanding – thousands of British jobs are riding on it.

The car also carries the considerable burden of being the long-awaited successor to the legendary E-Type. Jaguar need the F-Type to have the same magic as its predecessor and the same halo effect on the image of the brand.

This week in Dubai, after years of waiting, I finally got the first insight into just how good the F-Type is, and whether or not it lives up to the hype surrounding it.

Just my F-Type

THE F-Type is the start of Jaguar’s new model revolution which aims to more than double sales.

Jaguar bosses know the firm needs another TWO big-selling new models alongside the F-Type to end years of under-achieving and give them a future.

Even if it is a sales success, the F-Type will only hit figures of around 15,000 a year because sports cars are a niche market in today’s world.

The two new models which will be vital to Jaguar will be a small executive car due in 2015 and a radical new SUV that will follow in 2015/16.

They will stretch the range, alongside the F-Type, XF and XJ to a five model line-up, good enough to take on Porsche.

But the F-Type is the catalyst to re-igniting Jaguar, a halo car to once again make the firm desirable.

This week, Motoring Editor KEN GIBSON found out if it’s good enough to carry that burden.

AS the Dubai sun rises on the Jaguar F-Type, it looks every inch the car to launch a new era for the firm.

After decades of living in the shadows of its famous past, the F-Type is the car that will decide Jaguar’s long term future.

Recent models like the XK Coupé, the XF and XJ saloons have all been very good cars but they have lacked the motoring X factor to make them irresistible.

The F-Type has that X factor, just like the 1960s E-Type — the last Jaguar to capture the imagination and shock the motoring world.

It looks sensational from every angle. Designer Ian Callum and his team have done an outstanding job on delivering a sports car that is truly desirable.

It has dramatic but simple lines, an aggressive imposing face and the fabulous rear end that looks like a £100,000-plus supercar.

And it looks like a car that demands to be driven, and driven very fast. Which is exactly what we did on the long, open roads of the desert outside Dubai, the perfect setting to put a sports car through its paces.

I’d been given the chance to ride shotgun as the F-Type underwent final testing before hitting UK showrooms in April.

Although I was totally frustrated at not being in the driver’s seat, I settled for the chance to find out how good the car really is.

And the first thing I can tell you is when you press the starter button, it sounds like a proper sports car.

Vehicles like this have to sound special, they have to make the hairs on the back of your head stand up and fill you with expectation.

And both the 3litre V6 and the 5litre V8 engines that power the F-Type make a deep riotous roar of intent that builds up to a crescendo of noise that leaves a glorious buzzing in your ears.

They both have their own distinct sound. The V8 is deeper, throatier, like a gun firing. It is more intimidating But the V6 has its own sweet symphony that will be music to the ears of any sports car aficionado.

So the F-Type looks and sounds the part. But does it deliver a drive to go with it? Jaguar’s chassis guru Mike Cross says the priority was for the car to be fun to drive.

It takes only a few miles on the open desert roads to answer the question.

The F-Type comes alive when you flatten the accelerator and it feels every inch a pure sports car.

It hugs the road like a second skin and the faster you go, the happier it becomes. This is a Jaguar built for speed.

And both the V6 and V8 supercharged engines deliver serious speed. Even the entry-level V6 has 340bhp, which propels it from 0-60mph in 5.1 seconds to a top speed of 161mph.

But it’s the 595bhp V8 that really blows you away.

I was literally thrown back into the seat when full power was unleashed. It takes just 4.2 glorious seconds from 0-60mph and the top speed goes up to 186mph.

As my driver, senior endurance test engineer John Winchester, floored the V8, it was obvious even from the passenger seat that this is a Jaguar capable of locking horns with not just a Porsche Boxster, but the 911.

And after a day on board, it was also obvious that the F-Type is the real deal, a pure two-seat sports car worthy of following in the tyre tracks of the E-Type.

F is for the future

THE F-Type is far more than a sports car – there are thousands of British jobs riding on its success.

For workers such as 21-year-old Thomas O’Sullivan, the car is the passport to job security for him and his family.

He has been at Jaguar’s Castle Bromwich factory for only four months, after previously facing an uncertain future on building sites.

Now Thomas feels he has a long-term future with prospects to develop a career.

He said: “There are real opportunities at Jaguar for a young person. I’m really enjoying coming to work and it’s great for me and my family to have a stable future for the first time.”

Working with him on the production lines is Mark Baker.

At 57, he is at the opposite end of the scale with more than 35 years’ experience at the company. But like Thomas, he believes that the future is now bright for Jaguar.

Mark said: “It’s the most confident I have ever felt about the future. The firm is on the way up with new models like the F-Type.”

It has been a rollercoaster ride working for Jag over the years.

Mark added: “When I started there were 13,000 people working at Castle Bromwich. A few years ago that was down to 1,000 and the plant was facing closure. But Jag have backed the plant and I’m looking forward to finishing my career here.”

Future Phil Livingstone, 61, is a veteran of 39 years at Castle Bromwich — and he also sees a positive future for the firm.

He said: “My job has been threatened a few times over the years. But you can see a real future now with the new models and the money they are investing here — and the F-Type is like sex on wheels.”

Another worker whose life is being transformed by Jaguar is 29-year-old sheet metal worker Steve Richings.

He experienced the harsh side of the industry when he lost his job with the closure of Peugeot’s UK factory.

Steve said: “That was a hammer blow but I always wanted to get back in to the industry. Getting a job with Jaguar is a great opportunity because everyone is very confident about the future.”

The workers are the human face of why the F-Type needs to succeed for Jaguar.

They are part of 3,000 workers — including 1,100 new recruits — taken on by Jaguar at Castle Bromwich to build the F-Type alongside the XF, XJ and XK models.

The turnaround is nothing short of remarkable.

Just a few years ago, in the middle of the double-dip recession, owners Tata were close to shutting the plant.

But in the end they kept faith with the factory and its workers.

They invested multi-millions turning it into a high-tech, highly efficient plant about to deliver the most exciting line-up of cars in Jag’s history.
